column10:
The best horror multiplayer game yet, and it will be a lot better on its V1 launch, hopefully. This game has so much untapped potential.

Also, this game offers you free unlimited sausage and eggs breakfast combo. Definitely a must-buy!
I never run in font of my friend in real life

Great game. Just wish I had a friend or friends to play it with more consistently. As opposed to the previous Outlast games, this one is more about environmental puzzle solving and completing tasks. It's usually scary your first time around but after that's over, it's more so about leveling, completing trials as quick as you can, doing the events, etc. Probably the best route they could've went to do a co-op Outlast game. Outside of the horror, it's a fun co-op game in general. The story... is there but it's probably best to have it explained to you by a YouTuber (granted I'm just kinda lazy); it kind of takes a bit of a backseat to the gameplay.

This was an incredibly fun game. At first I regretted buying when even the tutorial had my hands sweating, heart racing, and butt clenched.

But as the game progressed, it was still scary, but more like an intense game of tag except if you get caught you die.

Also, I swear... Gooseberry is an athlete in a fat suit. So damn fast lol

Outlast Trials was a happy surprise of a game and in my opinion, a must-play, especially with friends. Each mission is unique and you are forced to adapt, overcome and get better while your heart pounds and palms sweat, which is an amazing feeling.

I have officially beaten the game once and it was a thrilling ride all the way through. Can't wait for more content!

You can play with a group of four or less, and by yourself. Its in online mode both during single player and multiplayer so there is no pause, for those interested in this game for "single player" due to past Outlast versions. If you can't go 30-45 minutes without pausing or learning to take breaks in between trials, wouldnt suggest it. From what I saw from a couple complaints in the forums and the few negative reviews, time management is something a player needs to learn how to do for themselves, instead of complaining in reviews that a game isnt offering them time to leave themselves AFK in the middle of a horror/suspense game. There is an option to end a trial if you are mid game and have to leave. Leaving a trial will get you a not great grade, but its not like you are not going to replay majority of these trials over and over and over again anyways. You can improve and change your grade/rating on each one. I have enjoyed playing both single and multiplayer trails on this game. I have had barely any issues or reason to dislike it so far. I just know when to adult and take a short break between trials to handle RL stuff.

Game is co-operative horror survival without the PVP Killer with a lot of visual gore. Killers and bosses are non-player characters. There is no PVP and hope they dont ruin it with that rubbish. There is enough copy and paste of that style already. Hope they keep it the way it is, because thats what makes it unique and stands out. The behavior of the AI (killers/bosses) is astonishing in this and just so well polished compared to other games. Buddies and I were waiting on the release of a Triple A game, and we all had dabbled in this slightly before it. Now that the Triple A game is out, we all keep itching to want to come back to The Outlast Trials. We didn't expect this game to be as good as it was, that it is now a constant thought in the back of our minds.

Update: I decided to borrow my partners steam deck. This game "works great" on the steam deck. Though I could not find the slide button and couldnt see it in options for game pad controls, but I was glancing over it quickly. Later in the day I got back to my PC but I noticed when I played some of the keys were not working. The middle mouse button for emotes in game was not working on PC even after I tried resetting it again to the button its suppose to be, my slide function worked half the time, and I would get a warning that my rig was not ready, and it wouldnt work, though it was fully reloaded. I would have to scroll off of it then back onto it, but sadly that costed me damage several times cause it would randomly decide not to work. I also did not have a controller connected to my PC, so that wasnt a reason for the button being off. Validating my files right now on my PC after the issues I was having and it was during streaming X program levels at that. So fyi if you try to run this game off of both, it could cause an issue between the set ups. More than likely the PC end more so than the steam deck. Didnt have any issues on my PC prior with this game and never had it on the steam deck till today. So just a heads up.

Update: 2/25/2024
Really disappointed they took out Easterman's Dialogue when you finish individual trials. It use to be he would praise or scold you depending on how good you did or how bad you did. Sadly a friend and I returned to it and noticed a lot of changes and sadly he isnt saying anything when you finish a trial, going back into the ward region. Tried looking into this but didnt find any information as to why. Super super disappointed with that. Hoping they fix it and add it back in. We really enjoyed that part with everything else in the game.

When Outlast Trials was announced, I was rightfully worried, as the last game I was excited for that was swapping its signature single player experience for an always online multiplayer game, Fallout 76, didn't perform all that well at launch. I remained optimistic throughout the waiting period and I can say with absolute certainty that Red Barrels has done the impossible; properly adapt a traditionally single player game to a multiplayer game that's fun to play alone, with friends, and even randoms. 

Not only does the Outlast formula work with more than one player, but the core has been improved by adding new gameplay features that allow the player to distract, confuse, and disorient foes; things that were not present in Outlast, Whistleblower, or Outlast 2, such as throwing bottles to create an auditory distraction, bricks to stun enemies, and helpful items like adrenaline shots to run faster and for an extended duration and lockpicks to open containers that may contain loot essential to your survival. 

My two major complaints at the moment are that there's not nearly enough content at the moment to keep me coming back day after day, but that can be overlooked as the game is currently in early access as of writing this review, and that performance on a 1660ti with 8gb of ram can stutter quite a bit, but again, early access.

All in all, Red Barrels has something truly special here with Outlast Trials, and I wish the devs the best as the game is moulded into something that can be a treat for new and long time Outlast fans alike.

The outlast trials has been one of the most anticipated games for me and it was worth the 5 year wait. I loved the original outlast games and playing this one was the cherry on top as it is now one of my favorite horror games of all time. The multiplayer in this game is works extremely well as it allows you to play with your friends which was one of the best features in an outlast game up to date. This game never failed to scare me to the day I got it a few days after release day to now, though the more you play the less scary it becomes but still has you worry and stress every chase. The outlast games have a special place in my heart as they are the games that never fail to scare me. If you want a fun horror game to play with your friends then I can not recommend this game enough as it is one of the best multiplayer horror games I have ever played and I can't wait to see what the future of outlast trials will look like when it leaves early access.

At the current Early Access stage the game is really fun overall, it has engaging activities and some variation from level to level in terms of visuals and objectives that are enough to keep you engaged and playing, plus on top of it overall it already feels quite polished and personally haven't run into any technical issues or bugs.

The only downside currently would be to point that for the price it could have a few more missions since it currently has 3 Trials aka big Main Level missions with then having 2 or 3 different sub-missions in these Trials that are made with the same theme and assets but that use widely different configurations, so hopefully the addition of more Trials is done successfully with time as it's mentioned that it's indeed their plan in their FAQ.


[b] Update - Changed from Positive to Negative: [/b] 
Unfortunately with the release now scheduled and looming around they haven't addressed the lack of content in a meaningful way aside from re-using the same missions with different modifiers over and over again (made even worse for the grindy seasonal events they had for a few cosmetics pieces in which you had to do the same missions over and over again), and the kicker with trying to upsell cosmetic packs content to people that bought in Early Access for a mere discount instead of just giving it as a sign of appreciation for their support.

This little light of mine. I'm gonna let it shine... Let it shine, let it shine, let it shine. -Sergeant Leland Coyle

There is so much to say about this literal masterpiece of a nightmare. 

Whether you've played the original single-player Outlast games before this or not is irrelevant. Outlast Trials stands above every horror game in the genre. The team at Red Barrels takes the coop horror experience everyone knows and brings it to the highest levels possible in terms of pure adrenaline-inducing horror, excellent animations & attention to the worlds detail, along with masterful audio that I swear will have you screaming wherever you play this.  

So what do you do in this game? You are a patient (taken against your will) to essentially an MK-Ultra style mind control facility where the powers that be force you to undergo "Trials" that are meant to harden you and make you stronger in the face of pure horror & this game has so much of it. 

Each trial is a different location that has been turned into a grotesque extreme vision of whatever is being portrayed. Your job once inside is to do what Murkoff tells you & then get the hell out. Or die trying. Each character or enemy you encounter is intensely scary and satirical depending on who you get (I'm looking at you Coyle) with what I think is some of the best voice acting in the industry along with truly scary enemies physically as well.

Nothing is scarier after running room to room and being sliced up with everything wanting to hurt you in some way and you finally find a moment of "safety" hiding in a barrel or bathroom stall and you hear Mother Gooseberry's singing muffled on the other side of the wall getting closer to you. Or hearing your friends screams over the radio as you hear them get brutally assaulted by "the dicked man" as he chases them attacking the whole time. This game really is fucked up. But in the best ways.

If you want a truly horrific coop experience that looks so damn good you'll wonder why other games in the genre aren't even close, with sounds that are so realistic you'll be holding your breath to not miss what's coming around the corner, enemies that are so completely terrifying you'll literally be screaming running for your in-game life like it's real life, with levels that immerse you in every way so much so you'll think you can fucking smell it as the lighting, sound, darkness, and all of the wonderfully done set pieces and assets blend together into what I swear is an experience you have to see to understand. It is the scariest game I have ever played and in the genre it's the best there is. 

Are there some negatives to note? Yes. Quickly I'll say this game is the best to play with a friend or several (4 in total). Having your friends there, or even matchmaking while dealing with all this game throws at you is the most intense juggling act, and keeping everyone alive is so not easy. So if you're someone who solos games alone, although I believe you'll still have an amazing time it will not be easy and you'll come out of it like someone who was lost in the woods for 10 years trying to escape. 
Are there bugs? Some, but it's been less than 5 in the 60 hours I have played. Some were graphical and I think we had audio issues maybe once. 
I know some people might complain there's a lack of variety in the levels but dig this: there are I think 5 main levels currently (with the 6th coming in a month) but the replayability comes with the fact that they take those 5 maps and when they add new trials they'll reconfigure these maps and change them in totally different ways, sometimes unrecognizable with new enemies, different layouts, different objectives and for me the content has not ever lacked.

Some stuff I didn't touch on that's still amazing about this game: 
The lobby where you choose your trial you get your own cell/room that can be customized with all sorts of awesome decorations/cosmetics from good looking to guts on the night stand (your choice) kinda like the Sims in Hell. All of the cosmetics are unlocked by playing the game. Each trial rewards you X amount of cash + rewards like clothing cosmetics which are great. In the same lobby you can also play mini-games like arm wrestling & speed chess (which happens to be like the best 3D chess game on the market for some reason?). 

I'm sure I missed plenty of good, and maybe even some bad but with this game coming out of early access soon it's already the most polished horror experience on the market next to something like RE: Biohazard but because this is a coop experience also based in reality I think this stands above that as well. It's so well done and I love everything Red Barrels has made here. Completely recommend this experience & I can't wait to play the Toy Factory level when the game goes out from early access which is soon.

[b]The outlast trials[/b] is the living definition of [u][b]everything that's wrong with a modern live service game.[/b][/u]

[h1]Pros:[/h1] 
[list]
    [*]Fun coop game
    [*]Wonderful voice acting
    [*]Amazing graphics
    [*]Breathtaking atmosphere
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1] 
[list]
    [*]Repetitive gameplay loop 
    [*]Linear progress 
    [*]Reused assets / map parts
    [*]Reused prime assets
    [*]Very few enemy variety
    [*]Dumb AI
    [*]Lack of updates / roadmap
    [*]Game's ending is rushed and lazy 
    [*]Requires a lot of grinding to get exclusive cosmetic items
    [*]Requires to complete all trials to unlock the ending (even when you rebirth).
[/list]

[h1]Score:[/h1]
[b]5/10[/b] (Mid game) 

Remember that this game was [u][b]delayed 4 times [/b][/u] and got [u][b]barely any content[/b][/u] ... I'm not optimistic for the "Full release" of the game and what it got to offer.

You start off rough with nothing but as you get good with learning how to escape, throw stuff at and juke/slow down killers. Combine this with objectives to do for each mission and finding resources. Its random as to how the levels will play out every time you start them. While it is fun, there are some technical issues that can sometimes get in the way, I think its a fun co-op horror game that is very enjoyable despite being repetitive. 

From my experience, once you have a good build going you will do well in the game. You'd have to go through co-op to get more XP and stages completed. Complete with unlocking all of your good amps, tier upgrades, rigs and upgrades for those rigs. I recommend unlocking stamina and exhaustion upgrades ASAP. As for rigs, I recommend unlocking stun, blind and healer rigs and upgrading those to the max. As a good starter rig, I suggest healer, because you can keep yourself alive and your sanity full. You can do the same for your teammates. In this case, if you can help yourself; you can help others. 

The key factor here is that this game a tedious Co-op play builds you for solo play. When you have good cards that you know how to play well; you will accomplish a lot. Also always explore the maps, look for items and a secret that be be unlocked (this is for co-op & solo).

Overall I recommend this game. I like it way better than Dead By Daylight.

This game is so fun and addicting. Learning the game and how best to play is a lot of fun and it feels very rewarding. The maps are confusing and it's easy to get lost but not in a bad way, it's clearly intentional and it makes it feel that much more high stakes. Leveling up and buying perks/rigs/pharmacy upgrades feels good and I like the badges as well. The reward system is very good overall. I also like that the same map layouts are different depending on which trial you select-like in the first set of trials, it's the same map but some gates will be locked off or doors will be closed. Sometimes it's difficult to figure out where your objectives are, but that's kind of the point I feel. Overall, I highly recommend this game for anyone that likes horror and gore. I'm looking forward to future updates!

Red Barrels invites you to experience mind-numbing terror, this time with friends. Whether you go through the trials alone or in teams, if you survive long enough and complete the therapy, Murkoff will happily let you leave… but will you be the same?
SYNOPSIS

Set in the era of the Cold War, human guinea pigs are involuntarily recruited by the good folks at the Murkoff Corporation to test advanced methods of brainwashing and mind control. In a world of distrust, fear, and violence, your morals will be challenged, your endurance tested, and your sanity crushed. All in the name of progress, science, and profit.
SURVIVE: SOLO OR COOP

You’re all prisoners of Murkoff trapped inside their facility. You can choose to complete the trials by yourself or you can tackle them in a team of 2, 3, or 4 players.
Coop is never forced when it comes to mandatory objectives but working together can be highly beneficial.
Whatever the number of players in your party, it’s about surviving and getting out.

Ultimately, your goal is to complete Murkoff's therapy and earn the right to be released back into society. In order to do so, you must complete the Trials and the MK-Challenges.
Trials are immersive story driven therapies that take a certain time to complete. Mk-Challenges are shorter therapies occurring in modified or redesigned section of an existing map.
HIDE OR FLIGHT

In pure Outlast fashion, the core gameplay involves avoiding enemies, hiding from them, and trying to run away. Murkoff will provide tools you can use to increase your stealth capabilities, create opportunities to flee, slow down enemies, and more. However, you will have to earn those tools and work hard to improve them.
The tools will allow you to
Stun enemies
Blind them
See through walls
Heal yourself and people around you.
Murkoff will ask you to perform disturbing tasks in each trials or mk-challenges. Only after completing those, will you be allowed to exit the Trials or the MK-Challenges.
CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION

Customize and create your own trial patient.
Your cell is your home while you complete the therapy, you can decorate it however you wish.
Choose your tools, upgrades, and perks to fit your playstyle.
Meet the Denizens of Murkoff’s Sinyala Facility in The Outlast Trials. Each one of them will try and help you get through the Trials in one piece! Think you’ll make it?



INVESTIGATE

You’ve been abducted by the Murkoff Corporation to undergo unethical experiments that will modify your psyche and behavior throughout the Trials.
Collect documents and items that will help prove Murkoff’s malpractice against its patients.
The Process:
Break the Self: Murkoff aims to break down the test subject’s fundamental beliefs. Aspects of self-identity are systematically attacked. Like boot camp or indoctrination, the goal is to force a person to purge themselves of anything held sacred or taboo, the things that limit their behavior. The constant assault on identity, guilt and self-betrayal eventually leads to them breaking down.
Build the Self: It’s a bad cop, good cop principle. The rejection of the old ideology leaves a vacuum into which the new ideology can be introduced. As the antithesis of the old ideology, it forms a perfect attraction point as the person flees the old in search of a contrasting replacement. This progress is accelerated as the new ideology is portrayed as harmonious and ideally suited to the person's needs. Collegiality and calm replaces pain and punishment. Just at the point when the person is fearing annihilation of the self, they are offered a small kindness, a brief respite from the assault on their identity.
Salvation: Faced with the stark contrast of the pain of the past with the rosy glow of the future that the new ideology presents, the person sheds any the final allegiance to the old ideology, confessing any remaining deep secrets, and takes on the full mantle of the new ideology. This often feels, and has been described by many, as a form of rebirth. It may be accompanied by rites of passage as the person is accepted and cemented into the new order. The rituals will typically include strong statements made by the person about accepting the new ideology fully and completely, swearing allegiance to its leaders. Saluting flags, kissing other artefacts and other symbolic acts, all solemnly performed, all anchor them firmly in the new ground.

Very fun time! The game really develops once you are able to use higher difficulties. Ranging anywhere from 15-30 hours of fresh game play. Definitely catered to an older audience. Each instance teaches you how to do some kind of important step that unless aware, you'll be generally lost when you start to do more complete versions of said trial. Trials span anywhere from 10 min to an 1 hour depending on the efficiency of your group. Recommend anywhere from 2-4 friends for maximum fun, but solo is always an option. There is a group finder but it can be frustrating due to difficulties finding people close to the same level of progress as yourself. Since a few fanatics have pretty much everything memorized, queuing with someone higher level than yourself can lead to them basically soloing the Trial. Overall I give the current game a 9/10 for anybody who likes horror types. My real complaints are with people not really the game itself, I only wish that the Devs release more content.

I believe this is by far one of the most bang-for-your-buck-game out there. 

**DISCLAIMER** I will say the things that I enjoy:
1.Progression in the game is very linear.
2. Creative styles to the game making you find your preference in play style. (Aggro, Defensive & Variable) 
3. The increasing in speed as you learn new maneuvers, shortcuts and preservation of resources. 

The things I do not enjoy:

1. What I found after achieving rebirth 6 times is the mundane and redundant aspect to the game. You definitely begin to hit a brick wall in this game for sure.
2. The development of the Antagonists is slightly incorrectly tuned, leaving us getting poor interactions and false hits. An example: When hit by a Grunt, if you are overlapping the Grunt you inadvertently become stuck between them and can sometimes die in one fell swoop.
3. Everything becomes so painfully repetitive. Yes, you're doing previous trials to become successful in Program X, but there is no real difference in Program X and leaves me feeling like "Ah, so they quickly worked something to kind of was our throats down with something.

ALL AND ALL: I enjoyed the come up of this game, having a full week of free time and an appetite to continue on with this game, my friends and I successfully beat the game in a week. There is plenty of content, definitely worth every penny! I would totally try and play this COOP and NOT alone! It's very doable alone, but COOP makes it so much more fun and faster!

I've played the rest of the Outlast series so i am familiar with basic controls mechanics and whatnot. To fresh eyes this game can be difficult to start with. after about 20-30hrs of gameplay i started to figure out the mechanics and enemy limits and worked out the objectives and maps to the point i no longer feel the fearful immersion i did at the start. Human condition amirite. So basically after 109hrs, i now feel desensitised as i feel I've mastered all there is to know about this game and am now at the stage of optimising my routes and aiming for A+ scores each trial so i can unlock the best loot. This game will reach a peak for me where i won't feel the need to play anymore and i'm going to guess within another 20hrs of gameplay.

I hope that there are efforts made to increase the fearful immersion in the game as the enemy AI can be easily exploited once their habits are worked out. Additionally a lot of the loot is a bit lacklustre and some feel like re-skins. I would love for there to be more prestigious rewards for become Reborn (this game's prestige system). Overall i recommend it solo and with friends and also not to give up when you're first starting out, because as the theme of the game implies, you will get better with time and exposure... For the package you get at the cost its at, I'd say its a steal. Another easy AAA game by red barrel and for an early access game its practically polished. It's everything you loved from the main outlast instalments with the addition of co-op. This is probably one of the better co-op horror games out there right now and I just can't seem to put it down. With crazy atmosphere in each trial and a good variety of enemies this game doesn't stop scaring its players. Even when it stops being scary your heart is still pounding until the very end of the trial. I really hope by the time they release a 1.0 version there will be even more content to mess around with and more hours to be played. Very few minor bugs are evident but nothing to stop this game from being enjoyable. Just make sure you got a good group of friends who can carry you through some of this games more tougher sections. Overall, this game in its current state easily takes a 9/10. I hope it only gets better from here

What to say? Red Barrels never fails to disappoint us with its fantastic sense of horror, suffering, blood, sweat and tears. The latest installment of this great series confirms the above attributes. This time in coop mode up to 4 players. The protagonists are laboratory mices who go through all kinds of endurance experiments similar to the Saw movies, in order to earn their freedom (which can still be earned in Murkoff or?). Hide and seek type of game also! If you are so nostalgic for the core solo gameplay, you can also play solo, but that is not the point of this game. The thing people are mixing up is that this is not Outlast 3, this is a brand new game (spin-off we can say) in the Outlast universe. Chronologically, Outlast Trials takes place before the horrors of the previous games, during the Cold War. I can say that the game works great, excellent optimization, without many bugs and stuttering. A rarity these days anyway. Trials are designed (judging by the game interface) to be seasonal. What does that mean? In my opinion, each season will have several Trials that will most likely be sold in packs (or come as free updates after completion). They just need to add precious content to the game that keeps it alive and people will surely love it! 
Surely I recommend this game for people that have group of friends to share horror together. If you think you are for solo experience, also this game can be fun! All in all, great idea, Im very glad Im here from very start and I will sure follow game development and contribute as much as I can through feedback!
You will love this game!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
EDIT (27.10.2023.)

After few months of waiting, finally we are able to dive into Halloween Update for Outlast Trials featuring new map, new variator, new MK challenges, new skins, limited Halloween time Programs after which Weekly challenges are coming! Very excited to play this game. A lot of grind ahead of us. Game is fun. Few bugs or lags are quickly fixed. I just hope devs release this on consoles ASAP to get even more players and surely they need to speed up update process (at least small updates per month will be okay). 
Hoping to see more of the Trials in the future, but my review after 5 months stays unchanged - I greatly recommend this game! It worth of money!
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

My favorite game! Even though I've reached the maximum level, the gameplay is incredibly addicting. I find myself playing just for the sheer enjoyment, appreciating the dynamic nature of each match with RNG ensuring a unique experience every time. Achieving an A+ on all the programs is immensely satisfying and makes me feel accomplished.

However, one minor gripe I have is that program X tends to get repetitive after a while. On the positive side, I adore the variety of enemies, Rigs, and Amps, which keeps the experience fresh and exciting.

On the flip side, I'm not thrilled about the repeated nerfs to the Blind rig. It can be frustrating when a favorite gets toned down. Additionally, the weekly rewards seem a bit lackluster, mainly providing posters. It would be fantastic if they offered cosmetic items like skins instead, adding more flair to the game.

I also wish there were more options for decorating my in-game room. Having a broader range of decorations would allow for more personalization and enhance the overall gaming experience. Despite these minor issues, my love for the game remains strong, and I continue to find joy in the engaging gameplay.

Don't let the EA tag fool you; Outlast Trials is probably one of the best games to come out in Early Access. It has enough content to feel like a pretty full game. It took me about 22 hours to get through the first 3 Trials, and I've added another 3 just doing the first 2 parts of the new one, and I haven't even touched the "weekly" trials they've added in yet, which adds a twist to the Trials that you already know. 

Let's start with the Rig: 

Your life line and one true friend through everything (until it gets disabled in some areas in the new map). You have access to 4 different types of rigs at the moment: Stun, X-Ray, Heal, and Blind. Blind and Stun are relatively similar, though the Stun rig gives you a little modified radio that explodes on impact whereas the Blind rig gives you a mine you place on the ground. X-Ray lets you see through walls and mark enemies as well as items for your team to see. Heal emits a healing mist and can improve your sanity.  Personally, I like to run the Stun rig, as I find myself running from enemies with very little idea of a plan most of the time.  Rigs also come in tiers, so you can upgrade them with tickets that you earn from gaining levels through surviving the trials. 

Enemies: 

The game has decent enemy variety. Nothing too crazy. Where the enemies really begin to shine is with the Prime Assets. Currently, you only have 2 Prime Assets currently in game and those are: 

Leland "Why you runnin'" Coyle and Mother Gooseberry featuring Dr. Futterman. HOWEVER, there is a third PA and that is Prescott Whitehorn, who will most likely be added in the next big content drop. 

Coyle is the cop that you'll see in the prison and courthouse Trials, and Gooseberry will be in the Orphanage and "Fun" Fair. The areas you find them in really attest to who they are as characters, as Coyle is very much on the "justice" train whereas Gooseberry is more whimsical and definitely won't stab you in the mouth with drill-duck. 

There are also plenty of other enemy types running around, including X-Ray eyes, A dude with a tank filled with gas that drives you insane if he catches you, a guy that will scream so loud it'll burst your ear drums if you get close,  yourself ( who's definitely not an imposter), and 2 variations of giant hulking monstrosities that will smack smack fear into you. 

I didn't mention one enemy type, and that's because he's not really real. He's all in your head, but some called it The Skinner Man. 

Maps: 

The maps in this game are amazing. Each Trial has it's own theme, and the theme carries throughout the main trial plus the side missions. There is procedural generation, so each time you play a trial again, you won't be able to take the exact same path, which is fun and keeps things fresh. Each key item is also placed differently each time, so you can't just run to the same spot each time you play through again and again. 

Each map is also littered with traps. Some of these are simple and don't really effect you like noise traps (broken glass or hanging cans), but some can really mess you up like the trapped doors that launch a spike into your chest and then proceed to emit a gas that drives you insane if you can't get it out fast enough.

Prescriptions and Amps: 

These are items that buff you as a character. They can't be taken away through the trial mutations or gates that disable your rig. These are the things that you can ALWAYS count on to be there. They do very simple things like give you more health or let you walk across broken glass without making a sound. 

Prescriptions go down a list like with your Rig, but you can buy Amps in any order (assuming you have them unlocked). Amps can make or break your build though, but don't be afraid to experiment.

Cosmetics: 

These are just fun and good looking. If you play well enough and "beat" the game, you earn one Legendary outfit, but the rest of the cosmetics can be earned by leveling up and completing trials for the first time. Some items are also available from the Limited-Time modes like the Christmas and Halloween events. You can also earn cosmetics for your room, which just lets you add a nice touch to an otherwise bleak and sad main facility. 

Overall, if you haven't heard of this game or are on the fence about it, don't be. This is what EA should be, and even on launch this game had so much to offer. Updates to the actual content side of things aren't particularly speedy (we waited almost 7 months for the new trial), but Red Barrels is going for the quality over quantity mindset. That being said, there probably will be a ton of content so long as they can keep dreaming up these nightmare scenarios, and we all know they can.

Lastly, if the Early Access tag scared you off originally, the game launches into 1.0 on March 5th of this year and will include another new Trial, bringing the total to 5 trials and hours upon hours of running around with friends trying to survive.

There are some things that DO need work.
For example: 
Enemy ai, it can be buggy/dumb at random times.
More difficultly and random options (like randomly selected mutators for each trial that's customizable). 

After playing for even more hours, there is some negative differences compared to the closed beta:

The animation when you alert the screamer and get stunned is gone for some reason (maybe they had a last minute bug with it?). And while this is happening you're still able to interact with objects and doors.

I FEEL like they've removed some lines or change them, as I feel like it's not as impactful as the closed beta.

Some chase music has been removed. But a couple have been added as well it seems. 

Skinner man before full on sprinted after you at times and it was absolutely terrifying. Now, when you get get psychosis it's just a walk in the park with him slowly casually walking towards you while he thinks he's literally him (he's not)

Overall: Keep in mind the points I listed are still very minor and very possible to be adjusted and fixed over the course of early access, which I'm sure they will be. The game is still extremely fun and if you have to money to buy this game... BUY THIS GAME!

Holy crap, what a ride! The Outlast Trials is now finally complete. Unfortunately, their version of Prestige is to unlock each new outfit (which can only be unlocked, then purchased) each and every time you complete the game. 

And since Red Barrel Games isn't cranking out new maps or new Ex-Pop's (bosses) on a regular basis, there really is no need to revisit this game again. 

It sucks, because I really enjoyed the gameplay mechanics and the maps of The Outlast Trials. Hopefully soon they'll support this game with worthwhile content on a monthly basis. 

I would recommend this game as there are plenty of trials to keep you busy for roughly a month, depending on how you play. Just know that there is nothing else (as of this writing) after the game is completed.

I'm not going to lie, as great as some of the Outlast games can be, this one has a very weird Goldilocks effect on me.
Let me explain as someone that works a full-time job and trying to enjoy The Outlast Trials on my free time:

Playing solo can be obnoxious:
You can play the trials by yourself if you want to, however you are more than likely going to be spending over an hour on one trial. Most of which you are hiding in the same spot If you're being too careful trying to slowly inch the objective towards its destination. Because someone thought It was a good idea to have way too many enemies roaming around in some of the same locations close to one another. Making it so that if you have to hide in those spots it's nearly impossible to try to do something without getting detected. And the last thing I want to be doing in my free time trying to play a game is spending most of my hour and a half in our trial hiding in the same closet for a good half of the time trying to avoid detection. It's annoying and frustrating to get through these alone, and it's really apparent that Red Barrels Studios primarily focused this to be a multiplayer game rather than a single player. However...

Playing Multiplayer can be boring:
You have people that play this game waaaaay too much to the point where they know exactly what they're doing. So if you're coming in fresh and if you have someone that is at least five times the level that you are, prepared to get carried.
I have had a few games where I was struggling to survive and try to find objectives to help out, only for them to mostly be done because the other people I was playing with already nabbed the objective and solved it without me knowing. Making me feel rather useless in my endeavors and feeling like I've wasted 10 to 15 minutes of my time roaming around aimlessly in hallways while everyone is moving at the speed of a bullet straight towards the objectives. And given the nature and layout of some of the trials, I imagine that some of the objectives are hardly randomized, meaning if you've already completed that trial, you already know what to do and where to go to solve it.

How to enjoy the game "Just right":
So on one end you have trials that are taking too long, and then on the other you have trials there are finishing too fast. Both, to me at least, our very frustrating experiences when trying to enjoy this game.
The only way I can think to be able to enjoy it is to play it blindly with a group of friends who also don't know much about it. Meaning that way you all can start fresh, learn how the game works together and playing the trials at a decent length of time. From the few times I have experienced it, I believe two players is the perfect number to be playing with. Just you and one other person, four people may end up ending the trial a little too early, even if all people playing did not have previous knowledge of how to play it. 

In conclusion, I would not recommend playing this game, at least by yourself.
Make plans to play this with someone close to you who hasn't played the game either and enjoy the fun and horrors together. I don't think I'm going to be able to do that now that I have knowledge of some of these Trials myself, and that some of my closest friends have already played quite a number of hours into this game.
That is my best advice to approaching The Outlast Trials, I hope some people found this helpful.

INTRO:

I don’t typically write reviews for the majority of games that I play on Steam, but I wanted to give The Outlast Trials an early access review before the full game releases in March because I love this game so much. Now this review is a short version of an original one that I had, but I had to delete a lot of stuff because it was over the word count. So this review will be me talking about the most important parts from that review. So feel free to skip ahead and read whatever part you want. This review might have some minor spoilers but I’ll try to not give anything huge away just in case someone new is reading this and is interested in playing this game. 

MY STATS:

I’ve been playing this game since June and at the time of writing this I have over 650 hours played, have all of the customization and progression, and have 116 Reagents Released/Rebirths. I pretty much have 100% of this game so far and with those kinds of stats I guess I’m considered to be one of the “Veteran Players'' now. I wanted to mention this to show that I’ve been playing this game ever since it came out on Steam for Early Access, so I know what I’m talking about.  

DIFFICULTY/CO-OP:

This game is pretty difficult for someone playing for the first time or for someone that’s never really played any of the other Outlast games before, so I highly recommend playing this with friends. You can still play this game solo and it’s still possible to beat the more difficult Trials solo. I also recommend playing with friends because this game is so much fun with more people. “Yeah, that’s the problem with teams…if you don’t win together, then you die together.” -Blisk. This quote from Titanfall 2 best sums up the co-op in this game. 

IT’S STILL AN OUTLAST GAME: 

One of my biggest worries about this game when first starting out was that Trials wouldn’t feel like an Outlast game. But trust me when I say that The Outlast Trials 100% feels like an Outlast game. It still has the running and hiding mechanics, it mostly has the same Night Vision mechanics, and Outlast still hasn’t lost its identity over the years. Which is something I can’t really say for a lot of other games that I’ve played before. And no, this isn’t a Dead by Daylight copy. I get why people compare these two games and talk about their similarities. Which is fine, but I strongly disagree with the small percentage of people that say that this game is a copy. To me, Outlast Trials is literally just Outlast but with co-op multiplayer, nothing more than that really. And another thing that’s important to mention is that this isn’t Outlast 3. Sure it’s the third game in the series, but Red Barrels have stated that this is a prequel and is not the “official” third game story wise. To my knowledge Red Barrels have said that they’re going to be making Outlast 3 after Outlast Trials is fully done, and I'm also very excited about that.

NOT REALLY A STORY MODE:

One thing that I will say that is really different from the first two games is that Outlast Trials doesn’t really have a story mode. The closest thing to a story mode that it has is the Tutorial in the beginning, and the Endings. I guess you can play the whole game solo and you can kind of count that as a story mode but it’s not really the same in my opinion. If you want to play another Outlast story mode, then the best thing to do is honestly just wait for Outlast 3 after Outlast Trials is fully done.

RELIGIOUS HORROR ELEMENTS: 

One of the core aspects I think that make up Outlast is the Christianity/religious horror elements. They’re present in all of the games and It’s definitely here in Outlast Trials. To start off talking about this I want to mention one very important thing: I’m not Christian/religious. I wanted to mention this to tell what my perspective is on this kind of horror, and how you think I formed this opinion. Anyway to start, the religious horror elements are really good and in my honest opinion I think it even works better than Outlast 2. I don’t want to talk about what happens in the actual game because that might be potential spoilers for someone new that might be reading this. But what I love about the religious horror is that it’s all on one map, and all on one program: The Orphanage/Program 3. Because #1: I think that the religious horror works best in Outlast as more of the side horror and not the main horror, unlike Outlast 2. And #2: It also makes the Program it’s in stand out a lot more, which I feel like all of the Programs should be: Unique. I absolutely loved the way Red Barrels handled it in the game.

SMALL DEVELOPMENT TEAM:

One of the things that I feel like I need to remind a lot of the people that play this game is that Red Barrels is a relatively small development team of around 50 people. Why is this important? It’s important because they can’t update this game 24/7. I’ve seen SO many impatient people talk about how this game needs to get more updates/content or this game will die. I understand why they think this, but my biggest piece of advice is be patient and notice that this isn’t like CoD where you have 3+ AAA game development teams working on this. No matter how popular this game will get, it’ll still be an indie game because of how relatively small the team is. There’s nothing wrong with massive development teams, but just give Red Barrels some slack. Sure it would be nice to see more, but for right now I think that they’re doing a good job with the updates on this game. 

REPETITIVENESS: 

Now one of the biggest criticisms I see for this game is how repetitive it is and how this could lead to them getting bored of the game. That criticism is honestly very fair and I do see why a lot of people think that, but I don’t know if this is just me, but I’ve never really gotten bored of this game once. I’ve definitely felt at some parts it got a little repetitive like trying to go for 100 Reagents Released/Rebirths to get that 100 Trophy, and grinding Program Geister to get all of the cosmetics. But I don’t think I’ve ever truly gotten bored of the game. I’ve also seen people talk about how little replay value this game has. Personally, I heavily disagree with this and I think this game has a ton of replay value. For proof, I just like for you to look at how many hours I have. To be fair, most of the replay value I got from this game is from meeting and playing with a ton of other people. If this game was singleplayer then I would have way less hours in the game. But again I definitely do see how some people thinks that it's kind of repetitive. It’s most likely me that just feels the opposite from this though. 

CONCLUSION/FINAL RATING: 

I absolutely love The Outlast Trials and I absolutely love the Outlast series as a whole. I know it’s kind of stupid to say this but the Outlast games have a special place in my heart and I still think the Outlast series are still the scariest horror games that you can play. And I think that the Outlast Trials is the scariest horror co-op out there. (And yes, I have played Lethal Company if anyone is wondering.) I think The Outlast Trials is my favorite in the series, but I still think that the first Outlast is objectively better though. I give The Outlast Trials a solid 9/10 and I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to play a horror game with friends. Or just want to play with friends. It’s obviously on the mature side, but you probably knew this by just looking at trailers/the game rating. I’ve always been very optimistic for this game’s future and I hope Red Barrels still adds more content for this game because I absolutely love it. I even have the 1959 Murkoff Corporation Logo as my profile picture on Steam.

- Sincerely Übercharge!, A Huge Outlast Nerd.

I think this game is a really cool concept and does a really good job of intergrating all the lore of the original into a new and fresh experience. My one and only issue is what I call: High stress jank. High stress jank is when you are being chased through a doorway and instead of shutting it behind you step back through it and make awkward eye contact with your pursuer. Let me start by saying that this game is fun, only because I have friends to play with, i have not once played this and went, "I can't wait to play this by myself or with randoms" because anyone can agree a game with friends makes it more fun, that's why the industry has exploded in games you play with other people with, because you get more sales and people generally end up liking the product more.

This game lacks in a lot of areas, I think for starters the A.I is somehow less intelligent than a fucking zombie, you turn around a corner and they lose you instantly, the enemies aren't even scary for a horror game and I never feel like I'm at risk I am just more annoyed at how animation based the entire mechanics are because this guy will swing at me and his hit box goes across the map and since you are in the animation you are forced to get hit despite you being far enough away from the attack that it shouldn't have hit. That COULD be a tick-rate issue but I still need to play some more to for sure rule it out, regardless any game with animation based movements and attacks are always going to be a problem when syncing to other computers on the servers.

I think the item management is a drag and could be better, like for example dropping and item, switching an item are all clunky although it is helpful when you can give a player an item, dropping and item or switching it out is pretty annoying especially when the item just drops to the floor and then you have to angle your cross hair right to where it is on the ground to pick the item up and sometimes it goes to where the item you picked up instead, I do not know if its dependent on if you were moving or its just a bug.

I think they need to have more enemy variety as well, its the same 5 types of enemies for every trial, big guy, girl with puppet, guy saying some schizo shit with a machete, guy who screams really loud, and scarecrow.

I hope that when this game comes out of early access after they stop getting concurrent players (i would say like 200 people or something) theyll take it out of early access to get hype or something and then the player base drops again. So I hope red barrels adds more meaningful changes instead of just pulling a call of duty and adding a bunch of bloat cosmetics and bare-bones "trials" that have the same 5 enemy types to drive up the file size. I would (as someone who wants this game to do good) like it if they improve the A.I. to be a lot more interesting and unique to one another and their own behaviors and interactions, make the trials more interesting, and make the game feel more rewarding.

Everytime i close my eyes i wake up in my small and cozy room. I can’t recognize myself in the mirror, or whom i was, was i male or female, it doesn’t matter… I remember a lot of occasional faces, many other people, some of them were my friends. My food tray is untouched everytime i look at it, also i have a nice line-up of aclohol bottles, too bad they’re not real, i would like to have a glass of corn bourbon…  glad i still have my coffee can. “Can you see it” says the poster on the cold wall. I think i can, clearly as ever before…  Also i hear constant voices in my head, palpable quotes, i can distinguish each quote and reproduce exactly as i heard them initially, first time ever…

My Lord and Shepherd…
“Be cool b*tch, be cool” 
“I LOVE YOU”
" Why you so anxious..."
"LIGHTS OUT"
"You failed because you're a failure"
"You will BEHAVE !"
" let it shine let it shine"
“You’re a spider”
"STOP RESISTING"
"It's a wild goose chase"
“….kill the snitch”
"Look at that smile. We're so happy. Not all of us..."

I don’t know why but i have pleasant feeling when i think about crackers and juice…And some phantom tooth pain comes alongside. I found a diary with some notes on my table, i guess they’re mine:

May-August.
first experience.
Tried to be a good team player, and i think i still am,   i helped those “we’re friends and inseparable, do whatever you want by yourself”, i protected them, shared stuff with them, was useful, but all i got is “will you start helping us, or you going to continue hiding ?!” couldn’t bare this self entitled sh*t, so i waited until they complete all valves in “grind the bad apples”, it took them 40 minutes to finally reach the culmination point, afterwards i ran like hell to the exit, got to the shuttle all alone, initiated the countdown, watched them get bleeding, executed, both dead, got so much joy for the rest of the day, grind the bad seeds indeed….


November.
i feel changes… many new faces around, someone said we will have real halloween, that would be great…
it wasn’t easy, at all…

December.
Try to help them all, all of them, even if they locked in opposite area beyond your reach, dead in few minutes after arrival, broke your silence, stepped trap, or creating chaos. merry xmas.

But as it stands it seems like playing on single player is nigh impossible with the high difficulty level of the trials and no way to adjust the difficulty settings. I understand it was primarily meant to focus more on playing together but thats not the best when none of your friends play or want to play. Please either make a difficulty setting level that can be changed of adjust the game to be better adjusted and scale to single player.

Outlast Trails is an exceptional game, The atmospheric design is truly commendable, immersive environment. The gameplay itself is a amazing, keeping me engaged and excited, ensuring that boredom remains a distant thought. The game has minimal bugs as well which is a welcome change with how alot of games have been recently.

However, the challenge lies in connecting with other players, particularly for specific trails. it takes ages and alot of the time will fail due to many different reasons and when you get into a lobby with a team the host suddenly changes to a completely different trail.

another issue is some players skill levels, even at higher levels, who seem content with staying in the background, leaving the heavy lifting to others. Unfortunately, the game fails to adequately reward those who actively contribute to completing objectives, reviving teammates, keeping people alive with rigs ect, a feature that could significantly enhance the overall gaming experience.

Overall, Outlast Trails shines when played with friends especially is a great game and i cant wait for the full game release, which i hope has more trails to explore with new enemies and challenges

If you're looking for a good time with friends, this game can provide it. Simplistic in nature, it has just enough depth to it to make it challenging and enjoyable. The thing is, DO NOT come to this game expecting a normal Outlast experience. You are not going to have a good time playing solo. You are not getting some huge story driven narrative. It is a set of "trials" that basically equate to 20 minute matches of completing certain objectives with team mates and trying not to get killed. You're not going to be dealing with a huge over lying story line and you are going to STRUGGLE if you aren't playing with friends or at least other players in these lobbies you will be put into.

TL;DR
Game is a great multiplayer experience with little story and only shares the Outlast name and mechanics.

Treat my verdict as more of a mixed reception. 

The game is decently fun with friends when you try to solve puzzles together as a squad. However, enemies usually camp objectives or have BS spawns and that turns it into a really frustrating and unfair experience. The game in it's current stage also lacks replayability, as such it forces you to replay levels you have completed in a harder difficulty. I've completed the game and 'freed' my character and see no point in playing the game any further.

All in all, the game has potential but can be really tedious to sit through. If you're looking to purchase the game, I would recommend you wait for it to be fully released or wait for a big sale to justify the purchase. I'm looking forward to new levels from the developers and I hope they'll improve the replayability of the game.

This game hits the mark with its blend of horror and fun. The gameplay is both terrifying and exhilarating, keeping you on the edge of your seat. Its standout features include unique abilities and perks for characters and levels, adding depth and variety to the experience. The game also impresses with its smooth performance, a testament to its excellent optimization. And for a quirky touch, check out the 3D chess in the lobby – a small but enjoyable addition. Overall, a thrilling must-play for horror game fans

Satisfying gameplay loop with all the usual Outlast quirks, but this time you can laugh at your friends getting their faces caved in by several naked and grotesque experiments rather than worrying about yourself. 
Comes complete with a dress-up sim and the ability to design your own bedroom. What more could you need?

Picked this up over the Christmas sale... and then played it every day of my Christmas vacation.

I really enjoy this game. My only complaint is that, generally, I prefer solo play over multiplayer and the number of objectives in a match is not balanced for solo players, so it's much more difficult to play solo than in groups, especially when you start.

Note that after a couple of weeks I'm up to level 15, have a couple of rigs, Rx, and amps unlocked, which has made the game much, much less difficult than at the start, so don't be discouraged if the game seems overwhelming, just group up with randoms and get those levels up.

The best time I've had playing a game in quite awhile. It's like Dead by Daylight, but actually fun. It reminds me a lot of independent titles like Devour or Lunch Lady, but much more polished with an adequate budget. The community is great and the gameplay is incredibly addicting. My first impression of the game left me in awe of how great the graphics and environments are. The difficulty is well balanced and the AI is largely competent and cunning. 

The Outlast Trials is an immensely enjoyable title for horror junkies and a must have for fans of co-op PvE games. Long-time Outlast followers may potentially be torn due to the lack of an in-depth single player experience, it's certainly to be enjoyed with friends.

Outlast trials might very well be the best co-op game I have played in years. While the game is in early access as of December, the game feels polished and excellent quality and care has gone into the game. 

Likes/Pros: your character starts off mediocre, a victim, everyone in the match as a villain NPC has more power than you and all you can do is run. The grind is not to bad, you quickly are rewarded for finishing matches or failing, you still get XP for failing. Once you level up, the game becomes so fun. 

Co-op communications are fantastic, the community is great. The modification to voice as you move through the levels is entirely immersive. For example, a laboratory or morgue will apply an echo to your communications with your friends in the same room.

Matchmaking, you may select to pair with people in the trials you want to do specifically, or the program or any type of available matchmaking. It's curated to support your journey through the trials how you want to play it.

When your leveled up, you feel powerful, you feel fast, you feel confident you can interact and engage and disengage with enemies. You grow confidence, and then you get yourself murdered from that confidence, it's so funny!!! I spend so much time on the floor because I think I'm going to go do this and contribute and help and save people!!! Only to get kicked through a door and end up crawling away from the beast of a man who assaulted me.

Cons: 
If you are solo and you do not like playing with random players, you may not enjoy it as much. As I will elaborate below, the community is very great though It is worth sticking to it. If you do not own a headset the ping system and emoticon wheel for communications is sufficient but it is much better with a headset and voice chat.

 I keep saying that I wish they could develop an ability to shoulder check an enemy as I am running. As this mechanic does not exist, I cannot help but appreciate the fact that they have given very little fight to the player because after all the game is supposed to have you play the role of a victim.

Do not be deterred by trying the game and failing right from the start. The game shines in co-op, solo play is ok, but nothing is more enjoyable than co-op. The community is spectacular. There is a lot of bad toxic communities out there for games and this game is uniquely not one of them. Everyone I have played with has not been a selfish individual but team focused, everyone I've played with who has a headset has been super friendly, educational if gameplay mechanics are not understood and in general an absolute pleasure.

I have never laughed so much in a game and I'm about 20 hours into the game, it just seems to scratch the itch of social fun with friends like you might experience in an escape room in real life but a lot more fun because you can cowboy and get your ass kicked for silly behavior.

The Outlast Trials

For the first time in years i played a game that i had insane amounts of fun at. The game is being selled for €29.99 and i love the fact that Red Barrels didn't add any way of transactions in this game for cosmetics or anything at all, the only way to get good at this game and get cosmetics such as Cell Decorations, clothing and skins for your character is simply done throught grinding the game, leveling up and completing new Trials or even ones you've already completed which will still reward you with xp, Murkoff Dollars and level up rewards.

Lore: The Outlast Trials take place in the year 1959 aka a couple years before the events of Outlast 1 and 2. The Murkoff Corporation conducts group experiments for CIA program MKUltra. You are a drug addict that lives in the streets and is one that the society wouldn't mind losing, so one day you find a poster/invitation to join the Murkoff Corporation Industry but why? When you join the doctors will make experiments on your body to change who u are to pretty much change society's point of view on yourself because they will understand that they lost someone important, and that someone is you.

Gameplay: In my opinion this game finally brings something fresh to the gaming industry after so many years and tears of companies ripping off eachother and releasing the same broken games over and over (Battle Royales, Arena Shooters and much more). The game comes with a great Coop mode which i would say is honestly one of the best we've seen in any Coop title. You can partner up with up to 4 people forming a squad and taking on the Challenge of the Trials together. The game came out 18th of May this year and since then they've added new in-game holiday events such as a Halloween and a christmas event and on top of that brand new trials for people to grind. As of right now the game features 4 different and unique Programs with their own and different Trials and Program X which you can beat to earn your freedom (won't touch upon this Program due to spoilers). When grinding this game you can unlock different cosmetics, Amps which are small abbilities that you either Sprint for longer, bash through doors while running, slide while running, make no noise when you step on broken glass that would otherwise make noise to alert enemies of your location and many more that even can't think of cause we'd be here for hours. There is a feature called Rig's, there are 4 of them and each one has it's unique abbility for every playstyle aka Solo or Squaded up. Rig 1: Is a device called "STUN" which whenever you hit an enemy with it you temporarely stun them and disorient them. Rig 2: is a Mine you place on the ground that when is stepped on by an enemy releases a "BLINDING SMOKE" that makes any enemy type blind for a duration of time. Rig 3: is a "HEALING CANISTER" that releases a healing cloud around you for yourself and your teammates if they are close to you. Rig 4: is called "X-RAY" and makes it so you can see enemies through walls and ping them for you teammates or is also really good if you are planning to go solo in the trials. I'm not gonna touch upon what missions you do in the trials cause that is gonna spoil the fun.

Characters and Maps: The Outlast Trials offer a huge variety of enemies, some more memorable than other but it is what it is, The First Trial you'll be mainly hunted down by "THE COP" who has a really cool design in my opinion and has a shock stick so he better not catch you roaming around. And the other one is "THE MOTHER" she is my favorite one easily, her voice actor did a great job and her design and lore is just pretty sick, her abbility is that she has a little puppet on her left arm with a drill in it's mouth so if she catches you then yeah. her lore is that she loves to skin people's faces and put them on Manekins and too be fair after you play Program 2 and 3 you'll realise that it's not only faces she likes to skin, super freaky and insanely cool at the same time. All of the Maps in the game are just way too good and really well designed to be honest, the game thus far has only four maps but even more trials so it's not one trials per map. this game has more content than what meets the eye at first. First we have the "Police Station", "The Fun Park", "The Orphanage" and finally "The Courthouse" until they realese more ofcourse.

Soundtrack: The soundtrack and Score of this game is just way too based and knows exactly what it wants to be without it trying to be a certain way it can't. Huge congrats on the guy who made the entire Soundtrack and the orchestra.

Verdict: The Outlast trials is as of right now on sale due to the holydays for about €21.99 and it's normal price is €29.99. In my opinion if you are a long time Dead By Daylight fan and you are looking for something new and more fresh of a horror experince, The Outlast Trials will do you just that favor. It's an amazing Coop game and even if you play Solo and have no friend you can still matchmake and find people to play with so you can make yourself friends and meet new people. This game is an insanely fun ride to go through even Solo or with friends and trust me, with friends? it's on another level cause this game is actually scary.
I love the games that are paid and don't have a battle pass system or any in-game purchases at all because that's how games should be, because it also ruins all the fun. Someone could grind their ass off to get a certain cosmetic and someone else is just gonna buy it with real money to just flex it which really shouldn't be the way and i love that this game is this way.

I'll give this game 10 because it knows what it's trying to be and the devs clearly know what they are doing, and let's not forget that the dev team is roughly around 100 people and when they made Outlast 2 they were around 20 people and just shows you what type of insane quality a team can put on a project if they are willing and passionate about it, Thank You Red Barrels.

I've been reborn, but I sure as s*** didn't find god while doing it. Instead, I was chased through darkened corridors by Leatherface's wife, that one dude from the Village People, some drug-fueled, Slenderman-like apparition, and many dudes hanging dong! 

Depending on who you are that sort of thing could be a dream come true, or your worst nightmare. I personally loved it, and feel that it's pretty much par for the course for an Outlast game. Red Barrels keeps upping the ante with this series, and The Outlast Trials certainly doesn't disappoint. It looks and sounds fantastic, there are plenty of upgrades and cosmetics to earn, and if you're like me and prefer to play through these games solo, you absolutely can do so without it ruining the experience. By that last part I mean that this is a pretty fair game in that it's not too hard to run solo, as you're given a few retries in a trial if you die, and you can even unlock more if you can find some pills. You definitely don't need to be some elite/pro gamer to do this alone. 

And sure, it might be a little repetitive, but if you stick it out it's worth it - the ending will blow your mind!

P.S.   Red Barrels - now that you're mostly finished with this, and the console release is on the horizon, give us Outlast 3 (please and thank you!)

"The Outlast Trials" was an electrifying experience from start to finish. Red Barrels has once again delivered a spine-chilling adventure that surpasses its predecessors in both terror and innovation.

The standout feature of "The Outlast Trials" is its cooperative gameplay, setting it apart from earlier titles. Collaborating with friends or fellow gamers to navigate the eerie Cold War-era mental asylum adds an extra layer of tension and strategy. Coordinating movements, sharing resources, and relying on each other in terrifying moments of chaos create an immersive and nerve-wracking experience unlike any other in the survival horror genre.

The game's atmospheric design is simply exceptional. From the flickering lights casting eerie shadows to the hauntingly realistic audio, every detail contributes to a sense of impending dread. The asylum's diverse environments keep you constantly on edge, never allowing a moment of complacency as you uncover the disturbing secrets lurking within its walls.

The developers' attention to storytelling shines brightly in "The Outlast Trials." The narrative intricately weaves through the challenges, keeping players engaged and eager to discover the truth behind the sinister experiments taking place. The characters' depth and the unfolding plot twists add an emotional weight that drives the gameplay forward.

Gameplay mechanics are polished and intuitive. The incorporation of stealth, problem-solving, and timed actions keeps the gameplay dynamic and engaging. The sense of vulnerability against the relentless adversaries and the limited resources available heighten the adrenaline rush, ensuring that every encounter is heart-pounding and memorable.

Additionally, the replayability factor is commendable. Multiple paths, choices, and endings encourage revisiting the asylum, offering a fresh experience with each playthrough.

In summary, "The Outlast Trials" is a masterclass in cooperative horror gaming. Red Barrels has once again proven their prowess in delivering a nerve-wracking, immersive, and deeply haunting experience. Brace yourself for a chilling adventure that will linger in your mind long after the lights are back on.

Alright, so I played this game called "The Outlast Trials" on Steam. Now, I'm not usually one for running away from things—more of a sit-down-and-have-a-brew kind of guy, you know? But this game, it's got something going for it.

First off, the atmosphere, right? It's like being in a horror movie, but you're the star. The flickering lights, the shadows, it's all very moody. I felt like I was in some messed-up episode of a sci-fi show. Gave me the creeps, but in a strangely satisfying way. Like when you find a fiver in your old jacket pocket—unsettling, but not entirely bad.

The co-op thing surprised me. I'm used to fending for myself, but teaming up with mates, it added a different vibe. You're all in this together, trying not to become monster chow. It's like a twisted team-building exercise. Who knew getting scared witless could bring people closer?

The puzzles, though—they're a bit head-scratching. I mean, I'm not the smartest bloke, but some of those had me feeling like I missed a memo or something. But hey, a bit of challenge never hurt anyone, right? Keeps the brain cells on their toes.

Controls, well, they're not too shabby. Took a bit to get used to, like trying to teach an old dog new tricks, but once you get the hang of it, you're off. Although, I did find myself running into walls more often than I care to admit. Must be a virtual version of my life.

Graphics are decent, too. Not Hollywood blockbuster quality, but I wasn't expecting that. The monsters, the setting, it all adds to the spookiness. I'd say it's like a B-movie that you secretly enjoy.

In the end, "The Outlast Trials" is a good time, if you're into that sort of thing. It's like a rollercoaster—you scream, you laugh, and when it's over, you're glad you did it. Just make sure you've got some mates to share the frights with. Four stars from me—solid effort, scary, but not pants-ruining scary.

The Outlast Trials

The games great, it’s really fun.

The problem is a lack of variety, mainly in the enemies, specifically the big figureheads. The Outlast series is known for its memorable killers and sadists, but the game only gives two notable ones.

Four maps but only two of them, you’ll be seeing them a lot and the intrigue and fascination wears off fast due to this. The generic enemies are done great but the major ones could be better.

Map design is great, gameplay is fun, difficulty can spike with the modifiers. Some difficulty ultimately derides from the maze like layout and sometimes same-y looking corridors and rooms, with no clear direction as to where the objective may be.

But that’s a problem only really in the later, more difficult missions.

Progression is interesting, it’s all stuff to give you the advantage which you will need as more and more is thrown at you.

Game just needs more notable characters and more frequent content updates, as with the start of early access to now, they’ve only added one new map to my knowledge. And with news that release will also only add one more, I fear the monotony this game will have.

Grab it on sale, 30 dollars is not a good price for the current state, but 20 bucks? Yeah that’s worth it.

When playing solo, always remember: 3 lives. 

Also, there's no checkpoints. Remember, no checkpoints. Get kicked because of internet issues? Start over. 

Were Idle too long because you went to do an errand or just took a little too long in the restroom? Start over.

Or how about you didn't even know there weren't any checkpoints to begin with so you quit the game and planned to get on later? Welp. Guess you gotta start the whole trial all over again. 

Remember: Solo gives you 3 lives. And don't forget: NO CHECKPOINTS!

Have fun!

 - Sound Design is out of this world, you will crap your pants. Even speed running through trials, you still get hit with jump scares that make you squeal.
 - Tons of Cosmetics and huge skill tree to unlock which brings you back to play more
 - You get addicted to the adrenaline fueled scare
 - Matchmaking is pretty good if you're willing to play whatever other people want to play

CONS:
 - once you level up high enough and unlock a chunk of skills and abilities, the game becomes a little easy
 - sometimes matchmaking takes a while when you're trying to find people to help you with trials, but easy solution is to join the official discord and find people to play with. But that's also a chore within itself.

OVERALL:
I love this game, I hope it has cross-play when the console version comes out so I can play with my friends.

Hello, i am a 49 yo single mother, maybe one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so he downloaded it and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do but he gladly helped me. loved it as it was the best time i had spent with my Son since my husband died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
