This game truly surprised me. I didn't know what to expect from Red Barrels or how they would pull off an online version of Outlast, but they did it in style. The hub is great. It just feels like a nut house. Only activities available are arm wrestling and chess, yet somehow I still found myself spending a ton of time in the hub messing with randos, beating on tables. Game play is fun, immersive and challenging. I managed to beat the first 3 levels solo with a D rating first try. The game is exceptionally difficult solo, but not impossible. I love how humble the devs are, encouraging feedback on how to balance the game and improve it. One criticism I have is that grouping up with randoms is daunting. They need to make a way to one button team up with people you meet in the hub (maybe similar to the way rec room does it?).  Definitely worth the low price.  Graphics and performance is A++

Its kind of like if you took Dead By Daylight, refined it, took out the toxic pvp aspect, and made everyone a survivor and added more varied objectives.

Now you and your friends can enjoy stealthing through disgusting twisted play sets themed around courthouses, carnivals, prisons, and orphanages while dodging traps and gangs of murderous mutants and lunatics.

The game loves its gore and shock value imagery. So be aware of that. Dicks, tits, sexual content, a racist sodomizing electro cop, songs about kids doing lines of cocaine, its all in here. Fully R rated game here.

The controls are smooth and the stealth is pretty decent. Enemy variety and behavior is also better than I expected.  You have solid character progression with upgrading your toolkit, amps, and questionable medication regime which all make you significantly better at this or that. Personally I am enjoying the stun set up and just hoarding batteries and chain stunning baddies while my friend does a loud objective. Which brings us to

The co-op. The game can be played solo, you get extra lives to make up for the lack of teammates. But it really shines in its 2-4 person co-op. You can break down heavy doors for better shortcuts or lift each other over a high wall or kick an grappling enemy off an ally. And this is where it starts to feel like DBD survivor bullying without the guilt. You can really get up to some Benny Hill shenanigans with the killers. Sure there are multiple threats on each map to even it out. But teamwork really can make the dream work here.

So if you want to group up with your friends and throw bricks at evil lunch ladies together its all here.

There's also a wide range of difficulties with earlier levels pitting you against maybe three threats in a map and later maps pitting you against 2-4 enemies per objective and then you start running into the chaos of fleeing from one and bumping into a giant before a gas masked goon hoses you down and a crazy person jumps out of a locker to punch your face in.

A good set of maps and varying objectives and seasonal conditions and rewards keep the game feeling fresh with tons of character unlocks, customization, and interior decorating where you can collect the most hideous wall papers the 1950s ever produced.

The game is fun. There’s a lot of trial and error but once you understand the map layout, enemy movement and which rig works best to your play style, it can feel rewarding to absolutely blaze through a trial in about a quarter of the time it took you the first time around. 

Another great thing I’d like to point out is the community. It’s been a long time since I’ve actually played a game with such a friendly community. You stuck on a trial? Go ahead and hit that Search for Group feature and get some buddies to help you out. You have questions? Ask the always responsive development team. 

In short. This game does a lot of things right when it comes to multiplayer survival horror. Sure it can be a bit repetitive at times, but isn’t that the point of therapy?

"The Outlast Trials", released by indie publisher and developer, "Red Barrels" flawlessly integrates a multiplayer functionality into it, while also sticking to the roots of its predecessors and keeping a singleplayer experience in check. 
Cons:
This game does have its flaws though, I feel for the wait we had (2017-2023) the game does not come with quite enough content. Though I understand that they have it marked as early access, a smaller team and there were complications with the pandemic. One thing I do not understand about the game though, is how the characters lack any memorablity how they did in the first two or even the whistleblower DLC. I do feel that there are hardly any memorable scenes such as "that" scene in the whistleblower DLC. It does leave the game feeling a bit dull at times. But this game definitely has a massive potential and with updates I could see this game being very replayable. They have laid the groundwork for an amazing game and now just need to continue working on it. Now those are about the only cons that I can think of when It comes to this experience and I would like to go over some of the pros of this game. 
Pros:
Items:
This game has a bunch of unique and fun items to use, (though there are the boring, (but needed) items such as batteries), but using the bottle to create a sound distractions adds a lot of layers and depth to the gameplay that can make the player strategically get out of any bad scenario they could be in. The bricks are also a fun addition, as this game can be a lot crazier than the past two so being able to slow down the enemies is sometimes needed. 
Rigs:
There are "powerups" in this game, also known as "rigs" that can drastically change the experience of the game, the rigs in no particular order are called, 
1.X-Ray, the ability of this rig is, as I'm sure you could guess, being able to see through walls, not my personal favorite of the rigs but it can have its moments. 
2.Blind, this ability, once again as you could probably guess, makes the enemies that you face during the trials of the game, go temporarily blind, this rig is another sort of lack luster one.
3.Stun, now I'm sure that this will be unbelievable to you but this rig actually STUNS the enemies that you go against during the trials, this rig is a lot more useful than the last two but it does not even come close to the next one
4.Heal, this rig is EASILY the best, this rig helps you and your team in the trials immensely. I recommend every player use this rig while experiencing this game for an optimal experience.
Map Playablity and Functionality:
This game has a (small) but wide variety of maps, you can go from playing on a map where a lot of fun activities are held, such as carnival games and boat rides to going on a map where most people would dead going, a school. But unlike its real life counterpart the school map in this game is very fun. Every map in this game has its specialties and its own standout moment but my personal favorite map in the game has to go to the police station. 
Atmosphere:
Though as you play more the atmosphere does dwindle a bit, the atmosphere is made very well and provides for some very scare, but fun, moments during the gameplay of this game.
Final Thoughts:
I definetely reccomend giving this game a try as it is a blast with friends and I think the game will just get better as time goes on and it is updated more and more. 
Final Rating:
8/10 (could change over time)

FEEDBACK: There is way too much loading, an unnecessary amount of waiting time between sessions, and then there's the loading screen on top of the waiting in between more waiting.

EXAMPLE: start mission, wait 20 seconds, go into the shuttle, wait for teammates to get into chairs to start mission AGAIN, get briefed on the mission, watch a silly cut scene, exit the shuttle, NOW YOU'RE PLAYING... now once you've completed the mission and return to the shuttle, you have to go go through a load screen AGAIN, then exit the shuttle, get debriefed and roasted by an AI before you can return to the lobby, but wait theirs one more damn hallway and a gate before you're finally back... NOW WERE FINALLY IN THE LOBBY... rinse and repeat.

SOLUTION: Load the game while we are watching the cut scenes, and get rid of the the time between sessions so we can play quicker. immersion is one thing, but to be slugging along waiting to start a game or to return from one that we completed is boring.

This game was made by about 50 people
It launched with no server issues
I and many others did not catch any bugs while playing
It has NO microtransactions
And it still feels like Outlast
And NOBODY talked about this game anywhere

The devs listen, they might not release a "major" update every 3 months like other games or whatever, but they do listen to feedback, change, adjust and balance things.

It really feels like the devs actually care, for the game itself and its community.

Its worth its money and only feels early access in terms of content (4 main "maps" 100+ cosmetic items, a bunch of lore files), but even then. You will probably spend like an hour in the first trial but the more you play the faster you'll learn the games ins and outs. Making you progress faster through each trial and programm. The rigs (basically special items you will bring into the trial) will help you overcome trials easier, and you can pick the one that suits your playstyle (or the situation). You'll unlock more cosmetics for your character and cell (your room) which you need to buy with INGAME money, which can be earned through playing.

I could say more but honestly, If you like outlast, having some fun with friends (or strangers, or alone) or love being fast, optimal and just all the speedrunning things in general. This is something you should consider getting.

This game is so fun, vaguely spooky but not nearly as intense as outlast 1 & 2. It's great with even just one other person but it is such a blast with 3 other friends.

I hope in the future we get more in depth customization options for the cells & more mini games in the pre game lobby. I got this game for $22 USD and it is EASILY worth that price.

The price is a bit steep for an early access title, but unlike some others this one is already quite polished. The game isn't very scary but can be hectic and fun with friends.  I recommend using the in-game vc over something like discord as it's tied into the gameplay.

The game has limited maps for now but new maps, missions, and modifiers keep getting added every couple months alongside seasonal and weekly events. The random placement of the objectives, items, opened / closed doors and traps give them decent amount of replayability.  Late game the modifiers can increase the difficulty or way you play the map quite a bit.  This combined with the randomised elements and weekly events make it so you can keep replaying the same maps and have it feel fresh.

Overall I'd say it's worth the purchase if you are interested and can convince like 2 or 3 friends to join you.

Overall a solid and VERY enjoyable experience imo, whether you want to play solo or multiplayer, fun core loop with a very satisfying endgame and events, as well as minigames in a well crafted social hub, and the new modifiers especially help to keep trials fun and interesting even after having played the "same" trials repeatedly. A great welcome back for returning players from it's predecessors and no doubt plenty of fun to be had for newcomers to the series who are into the genre as well!

This game has great potential but there are such glaring issues that need to be addressed, however it's been out for 6 months with no fixes so it looks like the devs aren't changing much.

Issue 1: Enemies camping objectives and new enemies being released near objectives, there is quite literally no incentive to play objectives because you get more experience screwing around. Playing objectives is so unfun and punishing it ruins any excitement you get, the entire game feels like a chore because of this. You might be thinking "oh just lure the enemies away", we've done that and they lose interest and run back to the objective, if you're doing co-op it releases enemies on the objective whilst your friend lures the camper away. 90% of this game is about sitting and waiting.

Issue 2: The movement etc is so clunky you either get stuck on everything or start doing a glitchy jumping animation if you slightly clip something, on top of that interacting with objects doesn't seem to work the way it should. I've died numerous times when I've run through a door and tried to close it behind me, instead the character steps back through the door next to the enemy chasing them and closes it on themselves. I could go on but there's no need, within the first mission you'll experience all of the clunkiness.

This game has great potential, there's no denying that but the awful AI and clunky movement don't make it fun. Missions are all about spending 90% of your time hiding and avoiding the objective or dying to silly things like getting stuck on terrain. It seems the overwhelming hype from the Outlast fanbase is giving this game positive reviews without considering the glaring downsides and it's a shame. These issues if searched online can be seen from the games release all the way till now.

Very awesome game. I find playing with friends makes the game more fun. When I play with randos, there's usually zero communication (or maybe that's just my luck with lobbies). Speaking of, lobby times aren't bad. The way to search for parties is cool. You can search by random, or trial, or program. Depending on what you search for, is how long it may take to find people. The official outlast trials discord is also a great place to find players. Gameplay is great for the most part. I don't really like the new changes (nerfing rigs and bricks don't have multiple uses when hitting enemies anymore), but I'm sure I'll get used to it and make it work. Enemies are really cool and powerful, with a good balance of being annoying and dumb. I really love the specials and weekly challenges. It doesn't feel like a dead end game. There seems to always be new stuff being planned and in the works. The Geiser and Winter specials were really enjoyable. Cosmetics and room decoration are also a huge plus, along with arm wrestling and chess in the waiting room.

What I am hoping for in the future are more rigs with different specials, possibly a "create your own" trial where you can choose the variators and how difficult (or easy) you want to make it. Another thing that would be cool, is possibly a 2v2 type of game, where two teams of two compete against each other in a trial to see who finishes their tasks first. The team who doesn't finish first gets gassed to death or something lol. Also, for the love of cosmetics, please bring us hats that have hair. I'm tired of being shave headed with a receding hairline when i want to wear a hat accessory. Or make hats and hair separate where you can choose whatever hair you want, the the hat you choose adjusts to it. PLEASE. That is all. <3

original positive review:
Been playing on and off since day one of early access. May seem hard at first but your character levels up very fast with prescriptions, rigs, amps, etc. Definitely the most unique and visually beautiful co-op horror game i've ever played. After a 100 hours of playing im pretty sure i can safely say this game to make more changes/updates/maps campaigns. i've been reborn 11 times now and its just been the same old boring maps/side challenges, i really hope they are working on a huge update rn
we need some variety in this game again cuz it can get boring.

also i really hope for more coop moves like helping your teammate across a big jump or improve coop animations we already have im not sure im the only one but sometimes when i revive a teammate (or i get revived) the teammate magically ports a few centimeters away making it look like im pulling up the air other then those few issues i have with coop its more visual the mechanics of coop are fine.

my opinion on the rigs they are pretty much alright for now but we do need a few more, in my opinion healing and blind are the META in this game for now (Meta means basically what most people use) i really wouldn't mind more rigs in this game.

Alright now for the good stuff, the enemies and scary factors of this game can really be shown in some places like: The Basement of the police station or any dark place while you are sneaking praying not to get caught. i had a moment where i was in a dark corner with 1 hp with no way out while mother goseberry checked the locker nearby me and left truly terrfying. 

Being chased in this game is one of the highlights. i have a few words to say on the stamina in this game, the newbies have no idea about stamina management nor how to identify stamina depletion in this game cuz the default stamina bar is horrendous without upgrades, many many MANY times i have witnessed a newbie/Friend of mine get caught by the police guy or any enemy and die because they didn't know about: Stamina management,There being a stamina bar at all,or how to identify you are low on stamina. alright for anyone new to outlast trials and you see this review, your screen slowly gets more blue and blurry thats how you know you are low on stamina and should start walking a bit, and yes i do recommend doing this in a chase aswell. Some people think stopping while being chased is a bad idea i agree BUT there are some exceptions like: Locking a door behind you and walking away,After vaulting obstacles,after making distance ect ect basically you stop everytime you have time to take a breather then keep running.

Also i kinda wish they add more gore related scenes like cutting someone open for an item/key or something like that im pretty sure they could make something really awesome with this game.

Alright thats about everything i have to say for this game this is easily one of my favourite games of all time by far, and i really hope red barrels adds more maps and campaigns for us gamers who already were reborn over 10+ times. Also thanks for reading this review of mine, Remember to measure twice cut once and ill see you in the sleeping room. Bye!!

Outlast Trials: Where Fear, Friends, and Flying Bricks & Bottles Collide! 

Let me start by saying that buying Outlast Trials for myself and three of my bravest (or not-so-brave) friends turned out to be the best and scariest decision we've made in a while! This game is like the thrill of a haunted house multiplied by a thousand, except you're not just a spectator - you're IN it! 
From the moment we dove into this immersive horror fest, it was like strapping ourselves into a rollercoaster with no brakes.
The proximity chat? Pure gold! 
Honestly, the Outlast Trials isn't just a game; it's a lesson in teamwork, survival, and how many ridiculous noises one can make when startled. If you're ready to be scared silly, laugh hysterically, and throw digital bottles like a circus act, this game is an absolute must-have!

Kudos to the developers for creating such a nerve-wracking yet ridiculously fun experience. We'll be stocking up on more bottles and bravery for our next session because once you start, you just can't stop. Cheers to the clown fest of terror and friendship! 🎉👻

I played this game with 4 friends for 2 hours. The tutorial was long but helpful. You can skip it if you want. The lobby had arm wrestling and chess, which were fun. The game itself was boring and frustrating. We had to push a cart and do tasks while enemies attacked us. The tasks were slow and annoying. The enemies were everywhere and blocked the cart. One of us got stuck in the gears and we all died. This game is not worth it. It has crashing and frame issues on high end hardware too.

Played 2 hours of this game with a group of 4 friends. The tutorial seemed a bit long but it showed you most features. We found out there was an option to skip the tutorial for our last friend. We sat in the lobby for a moment arm wrestling fools that came around. When we got into our first game, we were very confused on what to do. We had some good laughs for that run but most of the time we were confused what to do. After that first run we sat in the lobby and played chess with each other then got into the second game. This second game made us dread this game. It was just constant push cart and do task while being chased by enemies. Those enemies are scattered around the map and camp the objectives that you need to do. These objectives are also not quick time events. They make you sit there for a few seconds holding down a button or pressing a button multiple times. If an enemy hits you while doing an objective you have to go back to and click that objective again. There were many times were if a player was in front of the cart it would stop moving. At the very end of that second game one of the players got downed in the gears and we couldn't push the cart into the final spot. We all got killed and failed the level. If you are looking for a good time this game isn't it. It is super repetitive and constant pain. The most fun we had was in the lobby playing arm wrestling and chess.

Amazing and Eerie

Red Barrels was able to capture the atmosphere and energy of their single player experiences and translate that into an online multi-player experience. Even with friends, the game can still be scary and at times frustrating, but it comes down to what you make of it. 

They tease or promise little and deliver a ton, easily surpassing any expectations. Very quality. Much wow.

Every update shows it was done with care and attention to details. They made the entire game very seamless, as even the tutorial is an important part of the story. They set up the lore/environment to enable them to make content updates for as long as they'd like. 

Despite being a serious horror game in its gameplay, the developers at Red Barrels seem to love fun, because they make the Sleep Room awesome. The Sleep Room for those that do not know is a 3D lobby where you spend your time away from the actual missions/trials, and, like the tutorial, is integrated lore-wise and story-wise quite well. They give your own safe space in the form of your room, they give you mini-games to play (arm-wrestling and chess so far; that's 3D chess btw) and they decorate for the holidays! Lots of wholesome fun in addition to the horrifying gruesomeness that is the trials; well balanced.  

Oh, Red Barrels also demonstrated how cool they are to their users already, like when they released an open beta last year for Halloween, so lots of people could test it out for them and demo the game. It was even then in a great state which is awesome to see in this current video game landscape. It gave me confidence that they would make an awesome game. I'm not sure how else to explain it, but everything is coherent and quality in what they do so far and I doubt that'll change. 

They move in silence but let their work show their merit for itself. 

Looking forward to what they do next! ❤️

The developers of this game have no respect for your time. Of my 20 hours, I think that 10 of them were spent in unskippable cutscenes. The AI are terrible; there are many instances where I should not have taken damage from enemies but did anyway. They also just spot you through walls. All of the missions are the same - there are less than 10 missions that are replayed over and over. The whole point of the game is to play coop; to play with friends - yet the final mission is solo and more difficult than any of the others. The worst part? It's not hard because the game is hard, it's hard because the game's mechanics are poorly implemented.

This game is not worth $30 for early access; and definitely not "more" when (if) the game leaves early access.

Key Points:

-        Unparalleled horror gaming experience
-        Breathtaking visuals capturing the grim atmosphere
-        Extended player engagement and rare gameplay elements
-        Exceptional realism in characters and environments
-        Immersive sound design heightening the sense of dread
-        Cooperative experience fostering camaraderie and shared terror for up to four players
-        Realistic portrayal of madness and haunting settings
-        Commendation for keeping players hooked despite age-related stamina decline
-        Overall, a masterpiece transcending the horror genre's limits


The Outlast Trials is praised as an unparalleled horror gaming experience, setting a new standard for the genre and redefining cooperative play. 

Developed by Red Barrels, it accommodates up to four players, creating an immersive and terrifying shared journey. 

The game stands out graphically with breathtaking visuals that capture the grim atmosphere of a forsaken facility in stunning detail. 

Its ability to captivate players for extended periods, coupled with rare gameplay elements and exceptional realism in characters and environments, adds layers of complexity and excitement. 

The sound design heightens the sense of impending dread, and the multiplayer experience fosters camaraderie, amplifying the emotional rollercoaster. 

The realistic portrayal of madness and haunting settings immerses players in a world that feels all-consuming. The reviewer, despite age-related gaming stamina decline, praises The Outlast Trials for its immersive qualities and the revitalization of a passion for gaming during the nearly 70-hour gameplay with friends. 

In conclusion, The Outlast Trials is described as more than just a game; it's a communal journey into the heart of fear, a masterpiece transcending the limits of the horror genre.

The Outlast series is my favorite horror gaming franchise.  There were moments that made me genuinely afraid to move forward and with the Outlast Trials Red Barrels have successfully brought that terrifying experience to coop/ multi-player. 

Outlast Trials is a lot of fun, both solo and especially with a friend. Aside from the nail biting game play, I love how the game has expanded on the lore for the series. I recommend hitting up the Red Barrels official website to read all the Outlast comics which add a lot to world you'll be exploring.  

Red Barrels have a gem on their hands I hope they continue to polish it into the blood soaked diamond it deserves to be.

EDIT: I played the first two programmes with a friend, but the last two programs and the final Program X I did totally solo. So the game is playable and very enjoyable on your own.

If you liked the first, second or both previous Outlast games you will love this game as it takes the best bits of both games and ramps them up to 11. The game still keeps the sense of fear and horror with out relying on cheaply timed jump scares.

The game is great solo but if your lucky enough to have friends then its a lot better although if your a sad loner who has no friends you can join a group with randoms. The multiplayer game play has embraced true Co-op game mechanics like the ability to scale high walls to make areas of the game easier also there is the ability to help a team mate who has been grabbed by a mob and of course you can trade items and also resurrect downed team mates.
The solo game play is set up so that players who prefer the "lone Wolf" experience can still have fun with without finding things too difficult.
The game has 5 different main story missions consisting of about 3 - 5 tasks on each mission and each mission takes an average of 40 - 60 minutes to complete. There is also "MK" missions that expand on each main story mission but require you to complete just one task and will take a lot less time to complete. 

The game runs flawlessly with no crashes or bugs that I could find, there was however a run where a patrolling mob decided he was going to camp the one and only path from a room and forced me to get creative and use the bottle throwing mechanic to distract him while I slipped past. I don't class this as or simular instances as a bug though as he chased me in to that room so IRL the mob would stick around while trying to find me.

Its worth mentioning that the game from the start is harder due to not having unlocked any passive skills or perks (Amps) also unlocking and levelling "Rigs" helps loads with both solo and Co-op runs. 

At the moment there is no "Battle pass" or "Item shop" but there was an in game survey that listed both of these in a list of things that you could vote on if you wanted them adding to the game so there is defiantly discussions going on in the background about adding them, I myself however feel if these do get added and that if done right it might help the game grow its player base a little by introducing "Battle pass" or "Item shop" results in lowering the price of the game. not to mention that Coop horror games don't seem to last long thanks to the cost of running the servers and sales of the game dropping off so if there was more ways for income to made from skin sales it would defiantly help with keeping the game around for many years to come.

The Outlast Trials is a completely different game and should be seen as such.

While it still is enjoyable in single-player, I highly recommend playing it with at least one friend. Running from enemies while getting to the next objective is much more fun when there are other players trying to survive the madness of the trials.

The enemy AI is pretty predictable, but that's not a bad thing. The variety of enemies is decent, in every area you have at least one enemy that is ready to chase you.

The Outlast Trials is Red Barrels' 4th entry into the Outlast series. Outlast Trials proves to be something of an outlier from it's single-player predecessors, with it being multiplayer, set far in the past, and encouraging the player to fight back, even if your efforts are temporary at best. 
Playing through the Trials from Level 1 cowering in the corner, thru Level 56 efforts to optimise routes and tool utilisation offer constantly new experiences, all of the time. Learning the maps and the enemy AI, adapting to RNG elements, and battering Coyle with an arsenal of 16 bricks is a never-ending fun. 
The menagerie of unique characters, the set design and atmosphere all build on the insurmountable standards that Red Barrels had previously set. 
Outlast Trials is a game that, while still in Early Access with it's flaws, is without a doubt in a league to be at an equivalent level to other multiplayer horror titans, like Dead by Daylight. Even after 120 hours (my playtime at the time of this review), Red Barrels continue to update OT with weekly trials, high-level trial shuffles for returning expert players, and events. And there are more core trials to come.
Coming from Dead by Daylight, it's refreshing to see so much passion and dedication put into a project where the goal is to please the players, not the company bank account.

When the game was released, the game was super fun to play with friends, it defo gives the scare factor. Me and my friends would play this for hours without getting bored. 

After completing most trials it becomes repetitive and boring. Yes, the trials are harder but its the same story line/same outcome. There isnt much to work towards other than new cosmetics/more kit. 
If you could progress through the trials, opening up the game to new bosses on each floor in the Murkoff Corp I think a lot more people would commit to the game. 
Right now, the game feels like something you would play to kill 30 mins while waiting for something else etc. 

There are only 2 bosses, Madam Gooseberry and the Warden. I feel like by now, there should be more than 2 bosses and a handful of trials. 

Id like to see more bosses in the future and some more incentives to play as right now there isnt much to really work towards.

The Outlast Trials is a great game of horror and dread best experienced with a group of friends. Teamwork and strategy will is key to have the best results in each trial.

To provide replayability, the game introduces a skill and leveling system. This system is a little lacking, as some upgrades should be available to everyone such as a slide or kicking. Some of the skills are also so good, that some trials are near impossible without the team having it, such as the stamina/endurance upgrades.

The game also put the lore/story to the side, and is very difficult to find from random dossiers in the maps, rather than the more active storytelling that the previous Outlast games give you. But this development is natural, as you are expected to play the same maps multiple times, and storytelling would grow repetitive.

Good recommendation to groups of friends, a small recommendation to the solo player.

Outlast Trials may not be as terrifying as it's predecessors (altough still a tad bit scary mind you) but its probably the most engaging and fun outlast game Red Barrels ever released.
Movement and mechanics work like a well oiled machine, the trials are amazing enviroments, twisted in every way they can be, character progression and customization works wonders, and well, the multiplayer, altough not mandatory to enjoy the game, really turns this game into a brand new experience.

The only real down side I can point to is the little amount of content available so far, however the devs are spoiling us with free updates left and right and a pretty meaty development roadmap to keep us up to date with the game's future.

That being said, got murdered by a huge man with his weewee out, 10/10 game

The developers are liars and here's why, this is not an early access game but a beautifully optimised. fully realised game that puts triple A releases to shame. It plays great on desktop and the steamdeck which is a nice added bonus. 
The Outlast Trials is more of the same from the first two games but this time rather than one long story you are placed in trials within the Outlast universe to be judged playing either solo or in multiplayer. Solo is a more sneaky experience at least till you level up and can be genuinely scary at times. Multiplayer is a a great laugh to play whether played with or without comms and can still be scary but the threats are more manageable with a teammate to help distract and save.
Levels are distinct and challenging, some may take you 5 minutes once you've memorised a route but some can take almost up to an hour and are multi faceted. 
One word of warning if you are new to the franchise, these devs pull no punches when it comes to gore and religious taboos, so if your a bit churchy maybe give this one a skip as some levels go beyond blasphemous but its all very tongue in cheek but no less brutal.
An intelligent and engaging experience that has loads of replay value with weekly, monthly new challenges, loads to unlock and of course the game is not fully released so plenty more in store. Big thumbs up from me.

The Outlast Trials, a reverse horror experience, has both positive and negative aspects. Instead of fear, you often find yourself laughing at the absurdity, with friends mocking you from hiding spots. The enemies, rather than clueless protagonists, exhibit hilariously poor decision-making skills. While the early access version introduces the cooperative horror game concept with memorable maps, it lacks content and polish, expectedly featuring bugs. Despite these issues, the game provides a fun yet uneven experience.

In The Outlast Trials, you and up to four friends face Saw-like "death games," combating gory terrors together. The story revolves around being abducted by an evil corporation for apparent rehabilitation but subjected to random murder scenarios. The lore, collected through evidence, adds mildly interesting details. However, the game's emphasis on over-the-top violence, lechery, and on-the-nose subject matter can be overwhelming. Despite attempts at humor, the tactless, extreme approach feels like edgelordian overkill.

The early access version includes three maps with bizarre objectives, such as transforming an orphanage into an unholy establishment or punishing animatronic children. These macabre tasks become chaotic challenges as psychopaths hunt you amid the noise. The game's intensity arises from completing mundane tasks under the duress of relentless pursuit, adding panic-inducing chaos.

The Outlast Trials is a unique cooperative horror game with a fantastic premise and some really memorable scenarios, but while the early access version proves the concept there’s a lot of work to be done to make those ideas pay off. Running around with friends as you hide from murderous killers and complete utterly insane (and sometimes too edgy for their own good) death games is paradoxically tense and hilarious, but the fact that the enemy AI is about as effective as a concrete parachute and two of the three levels share too much of the same DNA certainly leaves a lot of room to grow on.

This is something new and innovative for the Outlast series. While the story telling similarities from OL2 return here, the gameplay is completely diffirent from the other games in the series. This time you have ample tools to use against your stalkers, builds you can make, and unique approaches you can take. While the game isn't fully out by the time of this review, it's safe to say that Trials is a great addition the series and a fresh step for the franchise. Red Barrels have a solid quality over quantity type release dates for their games which I appreciate very much. The team is extremely dedicated and value the money and time you devote to the game, so they try the make the best product they can. This is sadly something rarely seen from game companies these days, and even if they are 'indie' company, I still commend them for this.

The Outlast Trails ist ein beeindruckendes Koop-Horrorspiel, das die Grenzen der Kreativität und Brutalität der Game Designer auf faszinierende Weise auslotet. Das Spiel nimmt die Spieler mit auf eine verstörende Reise, die sich perfekt für alle eignet, die nach einem intensiven und gemeinschaftlichen Gruselerlebnis suchen.

Die Kreativität der Game Designer zeigt sich in jeder Ecke des Spiels, von den makabren Umgebungen bis zu den beängstigenden Kreaturen, die die Spieler verfolgen. Es ist erstaunlich, wie tief die Entwickler in die Dunkelheit der menschlichen Psyche eingetaucht sind, um eine Atmosphäre zu schaffen, die selbst den mutigsten Spieler erschauern lässt. The Outlast Trails spielt gekonnt mit den Ängsten der Spieler und liefert Momente, die unter die Haut gehen.

Ein herausragendes Merkmal des Spiels ist die perfekte Interaktion zwischen den Spielern. Das kooperative Gameplay ermöglicht es den Spielern, sich auf innovative Weise miteinander zu verbinden, sei es durch das gemeinsame Überwinden von Hindernissen oder das Teilen von Ressourcen. Dies schafft nicht nur eine immersive Spielerfahrung, sondern fördert auch die Teamarbeit und Zusammenarbeit, um den schaurigen Herausforderungen des Spiels gemeinsam zu begegnen.

Die Entwickler haben auch in der Lobby des Spiels für Abwechslung gesorgt, indem sie unterhaltsame Features wie Schach oder Armdrücken eingebaut haben. Diese kleinen Details tragen dazu bei, die Atmosphäre aufzulockern und den Spielern eine willkommene Atempause zwischen den nervenaufreibenden Horrorsequenzen zu bieten.

Insgesamt kann The Outlast Trails allen Horrorfans wärmstens empfohlen werden, die nach einem intensiven und gemeinschaftlichen Spielerlebnis suchen. Die verstörende Kreativität der Game Designer, die perfekte Interaktion zwischen den Spielern und die unterhaltsamen Features in der Lobby machen dieses Koop-Horrorspiel zu einem Must-Have für alle, die sich dem Grauen gemeinsam stellen wollen. Wer The Outlast Trails noch nicht hat, sollte es definitiv in Erwägung ziehen, dieses fesselnde Spiel zu kaufen.

The Outlast Trials is a coop-focused level-based survival game, with a great feeling of atmosphere and gameplay. With friends it's definitetly fun, alone you will probably won't have so much fun as in Outlast 1 & 2.

It's more a challenging game to master those trials. For some casual playing at a evening with friends it's quite funny, after a time probably too boring because of the lack of content. If you've friends who love to grind some cosmetics and little perks, you will have the fun of your life.

Great performance for a Early Access (in comparison to other releases this and the last 3 years, it's insane how good this game is optimized), some bugs still available but overall a neatless experience.

For all real horror fans; wait for the official third Outlast game... this one is only interesting in solo for challenge-enthusiasts.

I was eagerly awaiting this cooperative horror game for a long time and suffice it to say I was not disappointed. 

I love the atmosphere of the game. The Cold War-era facility is well made, and the sound design with the buzzers and the unsettling voice-overs in Murkoff is superb. Props to the voice actors as well. Their performances give a distinct character to each of the enemies, even those with fewer lines.

The co-op is fun and adds a lot of strategy to the game as you work together to evade enemies while getting objectives done. Although the cooperative gameplay is thrilling, it's not particularly scary. In my opinion, the co-op aspect diminishes the scariness of the game, compared to a solo experience.

I'm also happy with the customization options for your character and the little room you stay in. It's all acquired through currency you earn by playing the game and doesn't involve any microtransactions (and I hope they never add any).

Right now, my only pet peeve would be the lack of replay value. Because you and your teammates are up against AI enemies, they become easy to predict and dupe after playing for a while. If you know when and where they will appear, they become more of a nuisance than a scary threat. This does make me put the game down for longer in between updates.

Overall, I'm impressed with this game, especially for it being in Early Access and I can't wait to see what the developers do next :)

Title: A Terrifying Co-op Descent into Madness

Review:

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

The Outlast Trials takes the harrowing horror of the Outlast series to a whole new level by introducing cooperative gameplay, and let me tell you, it's a heart-pounding experience like no other. As a long-time fan of the franchise, I was eagerly awaiting this installment, and it did not disappoint.

The atmosphere is as chilling as ever, with the abandoned Cold War-era facility setting the stage for a psychological thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The Outlast Trials successfully maintains the trademark tension and fear that the series is known for, and the addition of multiplayer only amplifies the terror.

The co-op aspect adds a new layer of strategy and fear, as communication is key to survival. Navigating the nightmarish experiments and eluding the relentless pursuers becomes an intense team effort. Whether you're guiding your partner through the darkness or desperately running for your own life, the shared experience of terror is both exhilarating and nerve-wracking.

The visuals are top-notch, with grotesque enemies and detailed environments that immerse you in the oppressive atmosphere. The sound design is exceptional, contributing significantly to the overall sense of dread. The Outlast Trials doesn't rely on jump scares alone; it builds an unsettling ambiance that stays with you long after you've turned off the game.

One of the standout features is the variety of challenges and puzzles that demand collaboration between players. It's a refreshing departure from the conventional horror formula and adds depth to the gameplay without sacrificing the fear factor.

While the difficulty can be unforgiving at times, especially when coordinating with teammates, it only enhances the feeling of vulnerability and the adrenaline rush that comes with narrowly escaping the clutches of your pursuers.

In conclusion, The Outlast Trials is a masterclass in cooperative horror gaming. Red Barrels has once again delivered a game that will leave you sleepless and questioning your sanity. If you're a fan of the Outlast series or survival horror in general, this is a must-play. Just make sure you have a reliable co-op partner—you're going to need all the help you can get in this descent into madness.

More Outlast for me (and my friends), yay! As a veteran of the Outlast series I’ve been eagerly awaiting the development of an Outlast multiplayer game for ages, and I must say that the results did not underwhelm me.
 
The game succeeds in replicating the atmosphere of the previous entries nicely. This can be seen in the amazing composition of the soundtrack, the layout of the levels, the horrifying visuals with the occasionally surprisingly high amount of gore and the design of the enemies which can create a lot of fear and tension. The gameplay is highly diverse and random which gives each map a great replayability. Another thing that is worth mentioning is the difficulty scaling. It is done very well with the introduction of the grading system. This encourages players to act more carefully and learn how to properly use items and gadgets. This is also accompanied by the evaluation at the end of each trial which shows what you could’ve done better. Furthermore, there are some quality-of-life features that give the game a nice touch like the arm wrestling and chess minigame in the lobby and the option to customize your character and room.

However, there is one substantial difference in this entry that doesn’t show up in any other Outlast game. You can attack, fight back and slow down enemies. This has not been done previously, thus making the game a bit less scary. The defenselessness of the original games was a big part in the process of creating fear and horror. Another thing I’d like to add: the final trial is unfortunately a solo mission due to how the game’s story and progression is handled. This is a negative aspect because you play the entire game with your friends only to finish it without them.

All in all, the Outlast Trials delivers the best possible version of itself. If I had to imagine how an Outlast co-op game would look like, I’d say it would pretty much go like this. It delivers in almost every possible way that the previous games have while still being in Early Access. Let’s hope we get to see this game fully develop with the addition of more maps, main enemies and maybe a co-op ending.

[h1]Dead by Daylight used to be my game of choice, but I fell out of love with it. This game has been the perfect replacement.[/h1]

I loved playing Dead by Daylight in its infancy. It was fun, it was my niche, and I always withstood the growing pains through its early days, and headaches it gave me. This game has been a perfect replacement, [b]without any of the growing pains and the headaches.[/b]

The graphics are unreal (minimum spec players beware), seriously beautiful. The horror aspect is done just perfect. Not too "scary", but also not for pussies. I can't even play alone, I've gotta be playing co-op. The horror is also perfectly balanced with humor. The circumstances of the game-being captive in a facility and being forced to run these trials of demonic and extremely brutal challenges-is so horrifying and absurd that it actually ends up being more funny than anything.

The gameplay is smooth and satisfying. Clearly the work of well-seasoned developers. I've personally never played any of the previous Outlast games, as I am not a fan of singleplayer horror experiences, but I can see why so many have enjoyed Red Barrels' previous work. They've done a wonderful job of making the game have a fairly challenging learning curve, yet still be exhilarating and absolutely worth playing for even the most novice of players.

It also seems that, the way they've set the game up, they'll never run out of new content, unless they have to stop putting time into the game (say if there is not enough active players, not enough money rolling in to pay the bills). As niche as it is, that is certainly a possibility, but I'm hoping it won't be the case.

[b]Bonus points:[/b] the dialogue and voicelines between the NPCs is just hilarious. Fucking cherry on top! 

[h2]My only regret is being too busy in the day-to-day to give this game the playtime it deserves.[/h2]

Outlast Trials is a First Person Sneak&Evade 4 Player PvE game in the Outlast-Franchise, which until this Prequel had only Singleplayer Versions being Outlast and Outlast II. While Outlast was highly acclaimed, Outlast II fell a bit short in quality, although it was still quite the frightful experience.

What's common to all three games, is the setup: You are being hunted by demented inhumanly strong victims of  medicinal experimentations, who are ready to maime you at any given chance in melee. While trying to navigate the levels you stealthly evade or try to outrun the AI controlled opponents, mainly by using battery limited nightvision and any kind of hiding spots like lockers or empty oil barrels. 

With Trials being a Multiplayer experience you obviously lose some of that "you are all alone and nobody can help you" feeling, as is with any other of these games, especially if you don't use the in-game voice chat and opt for discord. Still, the game is plenty difficult and can be refreshingly exhilerating when you finally achieved your mission objective and try to get safely back to your extraction point while all hell breaks lose and every enemy on the map seems to center onto the extraction area.

There are some points that dampen the experience, connection problems leading to disconnects of your coplayers (and the inability to reconnect, once you are out you get a fail), some random enemy spawns that will always know your exact position even navigating through vents or hiding in far distanced dead ends and that can be only avoided by hiding in a locker in time, and a somewhat limited map selection. Especially the last part is problematic for longtime enjoyment, given that players have to replay every map in various difficulties and handicaps as a padding for content prolongment until they are finally allowed to the endgame level. Paired with various ability-trees that have to be unlocked by currency only given out upon initial mission clears the long time motiviation and skill wall is somewhat unfriendly for the general public in my opinion. 

Still, the game IS fun and, more importantly, still in Early Access, so I hope they can iron out some of these annoying corners.
This game perfectly mimics what Outlast 1 and 2 did and moves it into Multiplayer. Love it!

The Outlast Trials is a first-person psychological horror survival video game developed by Red Barrels, serving as a prequel to the first two games. The game features four distinct character classes and skill trees, each with unique abilities. Players must complete tasks while evading monstrous enemies, using night-vision goggles to navigate dim-lit areas. They can only carry three items at a time and cannot directly fight enemies. The game was teased in October 2019 and is not a direct sequel to Outlast 2. The game was delayed to 2022 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a closed beta available from October 28 to November 1, 2022. The full version was announced in early access on May 18, 2023, for Microsoft Windows. The game's development team consists of around 40 people.

If you're looking for a fun, horror game to enjoy either by yourself or with a buddy, this game is for you. The Outlast Trials is a very intriguing game that provides hours of entertainment. From the character lore, all the way to the game-play, its a must have title for those who seek thrill, and want to experience what the developers have to offer. I recommend this product because its just linear enough to be engaging as I mentioned before, and also wide open with player choice, but not to the point where you'd feel lost or stuck.

Pros: 
1. Good game-play: If you like the dead by daylight style of game-play then you'll love this. The chase is the whole aspect of the game, you micromanage your supplies and get chased. 
2. Visuals: Its a simple concept, but the game looks amazing. The blood and gore are spot on. The wood, stone, metal, and even the enemy design is amazing.
3. Community: The player-base for this game is equally good. Very friendly and open to teach if you do not understand the game.
4. Repeatable game-play loop: As mentioned, the game-play loop is similar to dead by daylight, so if you enjoy the chase then the trials will be repeatable for a long time.
5. Intensity: The trials hold a intense feel the whole time, from murdering people to throwing hearts at targets, you'll get shocked once and a while at what your really doing if you pay attention. Not to mention the actual chases and hiding is intensive as well if you want to get that high grade.
6. Items: There is a wide assortment of different cosmetic items that you can collect. Each time you complete a trial or level up you unlock a new item for you to use on your character, which gives your character a sense of identity. 
7. Grade system: Each time you finish a trial you get a grade showing how well you did. The amount of times my friends and I have played through trials to get that A+ is astronomical.
8. Friends: This game has the same style as a party game so its made to be played with friends (But every game is more fun with friends so take this as you will)

Cons:
1. Repeatability: If you do not enjoy playing the same content over and over again with small differences then don't bother.
2. Performance: If you do not have a strong computer, then you will not be able to run this game. Before I had got the computer I have now, I had a lower end computer and ran the game at 30 - 45 fps (Can be dismissed if you have a good computer)
3. Difficulty: Once you understand the basics of the game, it becomes a easy game to play. In fact, the "Hardest" trials become so easy that the trials without modifiers become boring with how little of a challenge they offer.

I have put many hours into this game, and I can say for certain that it is a amazing game. I can fully recommend this title with high regard. If you enjoy the scary atmosphere, intense chase, hide and seek style, you'll will absolutely not regret buying this game.

This new Outlast, which is a prequel of the first games, is a nice change of scenario, however there is some lack of terror with clumsy “jumpscares” and usually not very frightening events. One should think, as a game before the events of the first games in the series, the change to heavy survival horror and cooperative was needed to build it. It still remains within the Outlast lore where violence and crazed up enemies are present, only from another era.

In every trial you must complete a set of objectives with different gameplay factors, some better suited for up to four players. Singleplayer is still an option but when it comes to primary trials, doing those with teammates is a must. As a guinea pig you must tread with caution, observe the enemies around, and do the best to outmaneuver their movements. Of course, there is special bosses who move and attack faster and harder than your regular foe. Stealth remains as a loyal companion but eventually you have to run and hide.

What it surprised me is that you actually can defend yourself (finally!) by throwing bottles and bricks, and using special equipment that stun your enemy population. No longer one has to depend on heavy stealth and shutting doors to stop anyone. Although if you don’t have nothing on you, or the boss is on your tail (as they’re only stagger by projectiles, but still vulnerable to Riggs), they become a decent option. Vaulting remains here and you can also slide while running. Jumping through windows and breaking doors while running remain available, but you have to watch for the noise you make, or someone nearby may listen.
Featuring coop moves such as rolling gates, barricaded ones, and also reviving are some of the features in the Trials. 

There are more items to use than Outlast 2 and you can share them. Everyone will have to take care of themselves as it remains the core of the whole game: don’t get hit, don’t die. It will seem selfish, but because even when reviving and healing, Murkoff will know someone died and it will have an impact on the group score after the trial. Triggering loud traps, getting hit, knocked out and executed, will lower your personal score. 

And that’s all there’s to it. You can buy cosmetics and better gear, but at this point there isn’t much to do, other than playing timed chess at the lobby. For a title still on early access, there is some fun and can be quite teaching to help new players, but it will get quite repetitive and for that I won’t be playing it soon until new stuff is released. It’s still quite addictive if you want to do what I did.

So goodbye for now, and don’t let the doctor teach you about dental hygiene.

As an avid gamer, I can confidently say that this game delivers an adrenaline-pumping experience like no other. From the moment I fired it up on my 4K, 144 Hz monitor paired with a 3080 ti, I was blown away by the jaw-dropping visuals that brought the terrifying world to life.

The co-op gameplay adds a whole new dimension of excitement. Team up with a friend and brace yourselves for intense moments of panic and teamwork as you navigate through the dark corridors and face unimaginable horrors together. Trust me, sharing the scares makes it much more enjoyable... or should I say, terrifyingly fun!

But let's talk about those graphics. Oh boy, they're a treat for the eyes! The level of detail is mind-boggling, from the flickering lights casting eerie shadows to the meticulously crafted environments that send shivers down your spine. Playing it at 4K resolution with a buttery smooth 144 Hz refresh rate truly enhances the immersion and adds an extra layer of realism to the spine-chilling experience.

Now, I must warn you, this game is not for the faint of heart. Be prepared to jump out of your seat, scream like a banshee, and possibly even shed a tear or two (don't worry, I won't tell anyone). But hey, isn't that the point of a good horror game? To push our boundaries, test our courage, and keep us on the edge of our seats?

In conclusion, Outlast's new co-op adventure is a must-play for horror enthusiasts and adrenaline junkies alike. With its stunning graphics that take full advantage of 4K and 144 Hz, combined with the heart-pounding co-op gameplay, this game will have you and your friend screaming, laughing, and begging for more. Just make sure to keep the lights on and maybe grab a spare pair of pants. Enjoy, if you dare!

The Outlast Trials keeps the spine-chilling essence of its predecessors while offering a new dimension with its multiplayer cooperative mode. The diverse programs and levels add depth, providing a range of experiences within the game. The blend of horror, stealth, and objectives maintains the tense atmosphere that the Outlast series is known for.

The game's attention to detail in creating a creepy ambiance, complete with unsettling visuals like gore and unnerving enemies, contributes significantly to the overall immersion. The contrast between the solo gameplay, which can be quite frightening, and the hilarity of playing with friends in co-op mode adds versatility to the experience.

Beyond the main gameplay, the addition of extra activities like room editing, character customization, and mini-games such as arm wrestling and chess brings an element of fun and interaction between players, diversifying the overall gaming experience.

Overall, the game seems to offer a comprehensive package of horror, tension, cooperative play, and additional entertaining features, making it an engaging and multifaceted gaming experience.

fun room decoration game

This game is legendary. If you're looking for a co-op, survival-horror game then this is the game for you. I haven't played any of the original Outlast games, but I am familiar with the series and its gameplay. My friends and I joined the closed beta last year, October and we had a lot of fun (and scares) playing this game.

If you're looking for a game that's horror, with a lot of jumpscares and terrifying moments (PT, FNaF), you might not find that in this. This game is not that, but more so horrifying, adrenaline-pumping situations. 

Outlast is a game about avoiding enemies, hiding, sneaking around them and, if worse comes to worst, getting the absolute fuck outta of there by running as fast as your chicken legs can run, slamming doors and using whatever you have to delay your unstoppable pursuers. The Outlast Trials is that, but less story, more gameplay with co-op. 

I know some of you might not get this game because of co-op, as it might ruin the horror of the game. First things first, Red Barrels did an amazing job balancing the horror with the co-op. The game is full of situations where you are separated with your team, confronted with unstoppable enemies and the only defence you have is a single glass bottle. Secondly, you can play the game solo. Red Barrels have optimized the gameplay for both solo players and co-op players.

TL;DR - The Outlast Trials is an adrenaline-pumping, gameplay focused, horrifying game that is perfect for both co-op and solo players, and I would recommend it to those who want a gameplay-oriented, survival-horror game.

EDIT: After 25 hours of gameplay, the game has come a long way already in support of the community. The new trial is amazing (probably one of my favourites) and it hasn't gotten repetitive or boring just yet.

The Outlast Trials is exactly what gaming needed at this point in time. Not only as a new game in a sea of dying games and recycled ideas, but as a refreshing example that there are developers and publishers out there creating NEW IP, NEW Genres of Games, and they aren't afraid to be the first in a particular space. Outlast Trials is something of a marvel to me. I played it for 65 hours in a 5 day period without even trying, and I don't even know why in particular it draws me in, as I have historically not been the biggest fan of most "horror" in general. 

At a base level, the co-op horror game has been done before, and some of them are even pretty good! But nothing has ever been done like this. This isn't just a horror game that ALLOWS co-op, but a game designed from the bottom up for it with engaging interactions between players. Every single layer of this game is a delicious treat of endorphins and dopamine from the engaging and suspenseful gameplay to some of the best customization options I have ever seen in a co-op game. You earn EVERYTHING in the game just by playing with no option to use real money on anything, and you receive a random cosmetic reward every time you complete a mission. Every time you play the same levels it feels like a completely different experience, and the bones that make up the game itself are rock solid.

The leveling/perk system in this game is FANTASTIC. There is always something to unlock or buy for your kit/character, and every single upgrade has a tangible impact on the way you play the game. There are different types of gadgets you can bring called "Rigs" which allow you to choose how you prefer to play and it adds to the already unmatched replayability by allowing your squad to run different combinations of loadouts. In regards to performance, after 100 completed trials I have never once ran into a bug, glitch, or disconnect at all and the one time a friend did disconnect mid game due to internet instability, they were able to rejoin flawlessly with 0 impact on our run. The graphics are immersive, and the options extensive with Ray Tracing support already optimized on launch. The controls feel intuitive, despite having no real precedent, as this game is completely independent of the other Outlast titles. 

Overall, I find the premise of this game hard to explain because there is no comparable. I HIGHLY recommend trying out this game with you and your friends, and it even holds its own as a solely single player experience once you figure out the levels. It may be somewhat shocking and scary the first couple times you play as it is a Horror game, but once you learn the mechanics you will be itching to get back in it and hone your skills against all odds regardless of whether or not you scare easily. 

11/23/23: Nominated Outlast Trials for my GOTY.

has some stuff that i wish was a bit better made like the Geister event (first in-game event). Clothing token price needs to be reduced from 2 to 1, and if its kept that way there needs to be more token gains from longer trials like Kill the snitch and Cleanse the children, those 2 trials take nearly 15 minutes to complete if you're not speed-running (and if u are it still takes nearly 10 minutes) you only get 2 tokens out of it when you could just spam Cancel the Autopsy  and get 1 token every 2-3 minutes depending on how fast you are. It gets VERY repetitive and boring quickly if you're trying to grind out tokens as fast as possible for every item in the event.

TLDR:

event changes i would love to see: 
-make event clothing and room items cost 1 token instead of 2 (costumes should stay 20 tokens)
-event trials that take 10+ minutes give 4 tokens instead of 2
-spamming cancel the autopsy/trials that take less than 4 minutes is faster than doing longer trials and give more tokens

Has potential and has medium replay value (if you want to get better grades on the trials, and unlock more cosmetics, or have friends new to the game). A bit pricey, and I'm hoping for a lot more content (there are only 4 programs at the moment (there is a 5th one, although that's just the previous 4 programs but on steroids)). Also, there is a levelling system to unlock new perks (AMPs) and abilities (rigs), upgrading your character (pharmaceuticals). You level up very quickly, and it's not a grind-fest compared to other games (Dead by Daylight). Very fun game and challenging at times. I've also spent half my time in this game just sitting in the lobby playing chess and arm wrestling people.

Outlast Trials is fun and a great cooperative game.  The first three trials are the most fleshed out as they were the ones at launch.  Trial Four was added a few weeks prior to the Halloween Event and while it is different and interesting is weaker overall.  This game is at its best when you are working to get objectives done quickly and able to run away from enemies.  Outlast Trials is a live service game and you need to be aware content will be changing and new content is added infrequently.  If you enjoy cooperative horror games this one is one of the best out there.

Very fun very nice, good scare and love playing Outlast with my friends. A very good co-op horror experience. It’s intense, challenging, and overall a very fun time.

Here’s the negatives:
-Keep in mind I’m bad at video games-
Just wish the difficulty would scale with how many people are playing in the level - it’s almost impossible to solo, but very manageable with 4 players. Its just very obviously designed for 4 players. If you don’t have three friends and don’t want to team with strangers, then you’re in for a rough time.
A friend and I played it together - while it was manageable with just two people, it tended to cross a line into “too challenging,” and we weren’t able to complete the first level without large difficulty. 
I almost want to recommend a way to control the difficulty of the levels (easy, medium, hard, that type of stuff), but also I hate those settings in games, and firmly believe in the “time to get better at the game” mindset.

That’s my only complaints with the game. Otherwise, its really fun and easily one of my favorite games to play with friends.
Highly recommend.

Who could've thought that this great horror series could be made even greater with the addition of friends? But that's the case with Outlast Trials. This latest entry into the Outlast universe is a haunted house ride filled with nightmarish encounters and thrilling chases in classic Outlast style, with an engaging gameplay loop that will keep you hooked until your next playthrough. Even though it's still in early access, it feels like a finished product. With the devs promising regular updates to come, there's no reason not to pick this up if you're a horror fan. Bring a friend or two, or you can play solo if you choose. But brace yourself—the horror within will spare no one in its relentless grip.

Awesome game, exactly what I was missing in horror genre. Has awesome replay ability, with tons of variators (also known as mutators) while item placements are randomized for most of items as well as objectives. So for gamers who like to dedicate and fully engage themselves into an endless horror game, while still feeling little challenged, this is for you.

I play this game solo, it gets little easy after some time.
You can just rush/speed-run it, but there can still be some intense moments. Especially if you need to loop multiple enemies in close corridors, while progressing objective. Pick your play style!

PS: Needless to say atmosphere is phenomenal <3

While still in Early Access, the devs have proven to strive for a well thought out game that has the Outlast feel and look, but make it fun and scary even though it is with your friends. Currently there is enough content for a couple dozen hours, so not the eternal live-service games that currently flood the market, but enough (re)playability to last you a month or two if you really like. 
Story wise, the game takes place before the first Outlast, and seeing the state of the trials, and how the original games have evolved to this it is a real pickup for an Outlast or general horror fan. Also the lore drop is exciting and finding new documents scattered around the trials is always fun and is a nice read in between trials.
Gamplay wise, while it is possible to play solo, keep in mind that the game was made primarily for co-op play. There are some systems created to make the solo experience better, but it just isn't the real deal. That said, the ingame systems for partying up are great and you can see which kit your teammates are bringing, which helps in organising (even though later on you will find 1/2 are way stronger than the others).

Also the sleep room (lobby) filled with randoms and being able to challenge in little minigames or chess is so much fun. Hope to see some extensibility in this regard as it brings so much joy to this bit of the game (maybe open up a new area?)

Can't wait to see what kind of programs the devs have in store for us. I'd love to see some customizability for difficulty and variant selection (even in custom/non-xp games).

Had to come back to my review and give the game even more praise than I did originally. Red Barrels went above and beyond in their vision with the fresh cooperative horror, The Outlast Trials, also the third game in the Outlast series. Players can work together or by themselves to complete Saw-like Trials, organized with smaller challenges in into 4 separate groups called "Programs", which are typically separated by different maps. With over 20 challenges and Trials in the regular Programs, there is not any shortage of content for a player to enjoy with their friends or alone. Not to mention that each level has randomly generated characteristics, so every run can be entirely unique in how it plays out.

If that doesn't sound good enough in itself, there are also hundreds of cosmetics to unlock all with in-game currency and efforts. It's such a fresh breath of air in this world of injected microtransactions that you will want them to actually hand over more premium cosmetics so that you can applaud them for the work they've already provided on the free cosmetics for the game for the price the game is.

Speaking of the price the game is, this is all coming in at $30 for Early Access and even less if you get it on sale. The fact that there are games being released for $70 with the quality they have is ridiculous when we are getting even better quality that Red Barrels provided here for $30. People would pay that price for the pre-game lobby mini games alone! Stunning AAA graphics, seemingly infinite replay value, phenomenal story that ties in brilliantly with the original Outlast trinity, and nothing but an absolute blast with your friends. The Outlast Trials is sure not to disappoint, as one of the greatest cooperative horror games conceived yet.

This game offers a great co-op horror experience, but it could benefit from more diverse missions, maps, and objectives. Still, it holds incredible potential and provides a lot of fun times with friends!

Playing with more people, up to 4, greatly enhances the trial experience compared to going solo. While some may enjoy playing alone and maybe even succeed, it's different from the older Outlast games—it's a new concept. One major advantage is the friendly and cooperative community, at least from what I've experienced. They're very tolerant of beginners, mistakes, and so on.

This game has the potential to be amazing, but it requires significant work. I hope the developers remain open-minded and, most importantly, attentive to the community's feedback. Communication and public discussions are crucial. I've already shared an idea I believe has huge potential—to introduce a parkour run challenge. With a touch of creativity, this game could evolve into something far bigger, better, and more expansive than anyone anticipated.

Best wishes to the developers—keep up the good work! <3

I have loved the Outlast Universe from the very first Game they released and been a sucker for it. 
This Expansion on the Universe and the Gameplay is super super Fun. I love playing this both on my own and with Friends. The Visuals are great, the Performance is great and honestly it does not feel like Early Access at all. It is super polished already and very fun.
The only thing I would say is a negative, is that Updates are quite slow. Since release there has only been a single Update with new Content which was Halloween. Now to be fair, this Update was great and I was extremely excited for the New Trial.
I have no idea how long it takes to put these Maps and Trials together so I won't say too much negative there. Just a heads up, don't burn yourself out too quickly because new Trials take a while to come. I do hope this is something that will change in the Future and considering it's Early Access, I do believe that Cycle will speed up.

Either way, I love this Game and highly recommend it. It is both scary and funny and I really love everything about the Gameplay and Atmosphere, it is very immersive which is impressive for a Multiplayer Game and I still get a bit scared sometimes after 50 hours. It's wonderful.

A twist on the original Outlast titles, The Outlast Trials revamps and supplements the lore of Outlast by becoming the multiplayer survival horror rogue-lite experience that horror players love to share with others. Work with your friends or go it alone in a twisted experiment set out by Murkoff to push their subjects to the breaking point. Outlast Trials is an attempt of Red Barrels to expand on the ever increasing trend of multiplayer horror games, and to speak plainly, I dont know myself why I enjoy it so much since the stealth-run gameplay loop is not original, but the game really manages to make its gameplay loop interesting, satisfying and addictive alongside its disturbing, compelling setting.

Starting off, this game is tagged "Early Access" but it does not feel like your average "okay very buggy and messy performance, lacks content" EA release, like at all, there are only a handful bugs that I can count on one hand that I encountered in my 80 hours of play so far, and the game also runs smooth as butter. So dont let yourself be fooled that it is a messy release and that it needs alot of work in that regard, it does not, it feels more like a "glorified content roadmap" release.

The core gameplay loop is to participate in trials/missions where you can - either solo or up to 4 players - complete objectives while running or hiding from various enemies and avoiding traps in parcour style. This works like a charm and has a funny duality, when playing single player it does feel like a proper stealth game where you can learn enemy patterns and patrols and play the game very tactically, while when playing with other people more often than not its chaotic fun and madness all around.
You level up your character from beating missions to upgrade either base abilities that permanently gives you advantages (e.g. more stamina), upgrade your RIG your "power" (e.g. a mine that blinds enemies) or perks that give you other strong benefits (for example to not make noise while walking over glass). These upgrades have a ton of weight and are the main reason you can do higher difficulty missions more confortably over time even solo. Which talking about the difficulty, it can be very challenging solo but from practising without RIG or AMP upgrades I noticed with practise every mission is very doable no matter how hard it is as long as you go at it tactically and dont rush like a headless chicken, and even if you struggle, the upgrades will carry ALOT, so no, in contrary to a lot of people's claims in the forums, the game is very doable in single player.

The story is the one point where Id say avoid this game if you want to experience it for that. Its basically documents that you collect in the trials and analyse outside of them to piece it together. I like it personally when games do storytelling in that type of fashion, but I know alot of people dont, and if you sign up for a compelling new "outlast campaign" you will be disappointed.

This game, just like all the other Outlast titles, is also again very gorey and disturbing, so if you cant see extreme violence or you dont want tits and balls flying around you (not literally) then dont get this game as well. It is very intense with its extreme content, now more so since they are sometimes tied to trial objectives [spoiler] like cutting the legs off of a naked dude nailed to a cross with a saw [/spoiler] . As a massive fan of intense horror, this is obviously much apprechiated.

Other than that there is not much else to say. This game is very fun and really holds me with its gameplay loop and atmosphere - mind you that I mostly even play singleplayer 90% of the time and Im still having the time of my life in a game that is promoted for multiplayer -. There is quite a bunch of stuff to do already, Im writing this as the release hotfix 1 version, and with time there will be new trials and other content on the way.
