Long time fan of Outlast series and this is an interesting direction for the game to take - Multiplayer - but true to its Outlast roots, its definitely not one to play with the family.

I've generally played this with friends, but I have done some solo rounds and some with randoms too.

General premise is that you're some sort of patient and undergoing therapy 'trials' for a shady corporation - with a view to eventually escaping back out to society. Not quite there yet myself... but maybe one day, if my performance is acceptable.

Trials themselves are sets of different maps, with different tasks to achieve - Map knowledge is important. The maps are never setup the same, a route you have in mind for a trial may not be easily available because of a randomly blocked doorway or something like that. The dice-roll randomness of how the maps are prepped I think is excellently done and the trials can be done again with harder 'modifiers' as you progress, such as harder enemies, more trapped or blocked doorways, less equipment lying around etc - Outlast Trials is still in Early Access and there is currently a handful of maps. The maps are highly, highly detailed and very well crafted, and there has recently been a Halloween event running.

Once you've got a bit of map knowledge, the game flows a little better - before you know it, you and your friends are sawing off the legs of a crucified naked man in no time at all!

Enemies on each of the maps are one of the main factors of play throughout the game - and also the most frustrating aspect of the game too - there are a few different enemy archetypes; your general stabby psycho, a few heavy hitting big dudes, a guy who gases you, a couple that respond to sound plus a couple more. Then there are a couple of 'main' enemies on each map - my particular favourite is Dr Fudderman who, along with her hand puppet, [i]will teach you about dental hygiene[/i].

Typically enemies are dealt with by kiting. A lot of kiting... to the point where its almost comical. Forget the tools lying around on each map, your best tools are running, evading and hiding - even though the game doesn't penalise you for how long a trial takes, there isn't much point hanging around, executing tasks quickly seems to be the way to go. Sneaking has its part, but in my experience sneaking is merely the filler between running and performing tasks. The best tool outside of this are bottle and bricks you can throw in the faces of your enemies when you're in a pinch.

I think once you understand that kiting is the game, and not thiefy style hiding and ghosting, Trials plays pretty well, although sometimes a bit glippy like closing doors under duress could be more fluid and when there is more than one enemy attacking you, it gets a bit clusterf*ckish. It's still Early Access and incredibly well made at this stage, so I can't complain too much here.

I recommend. The entire game looks great, amazingly optimised. I'm excited to see how it progresses through Early Access to release.

I really enjoy playing this game with friends! It is scary/thrilling, but a lot of fun as well. I have completed rebirth twice, only because my heart beats so loudly when I play solo. Lolol.

Not too bad for early access, although there are a few bugs at times (which is to be expected). I hope more rigs, amps, customization options, and enemies/maps/trials are added once the game is fully released.

Omega trials are a bit more difficult than all other trials, with some of them having very minimal items (one health potion, one battery, one antidote) and no rigs. When having to electrocute the snitch, the enemies seem to always camp where we need to be, so we end up with an inability to complete the trial. I am sure we all hate being called a failure, haha.

Arm wrestling with everyone was a neat addition, and it aids in the preparation of opening locks. They added speed chess as well, which is pretty fun.

The Halloween event (Program Geister) was cool, but it would be nice if we had more time after the event ended to use up our tokens. There were a lot of cosmetics I unlocked, but missed out on purchasing. :(

All in all, still a pretty fun game to play with friends. Here's hoping for a Christmas event and/or cosmetics~!

[h1] The best Outlast game [/h1]
[b]A defintive journey into the Outlast universe, with all the nudity the previous games had to offer, but you're no longer alone [/b]
Having played all three Outlast games now, this one is currently standing strong and proud as my favourite of the bunch. Sure, it may not journey to the psychological horrors that 2 would throw at me, nor is it perhaps as Iconic as Mount Massive, but the amount of theoretical content this game will have in the future, with many updates yet to come, constant new programs coming out, not to mention all the sheer character that the Programs and their many Antagonists exhibit is paramount to phenomenal!

[h2]Did I mention that this is the single game I've seen thus far that has actual accessibility options for Tinnitus?![/h2]
The depths of customisation this game allows you to access in its settings alone should become the new standard. Graphical fidelity settings are varied and allow people with all kinds of rigs to run the game, not to mention the accessibility options available which help more than a few of my friends get the very best experience possible.

[h2] Characterisation is Strong [/h2]
The enemies in this game vary in a few ways. At time of writing we have;
2 Outstanding recurring major antagonists which will hunt us down throughout the many trials.
A Myriad of side opponents from Slashers, Shriekers, Giants, Psychological Gas wielding maniacs and Night Vision lurkers
Not to mention the many, many hidden nutjobs hiding in nooks and crannies, let alone the imposters which will regularly make an appearance and try to trick you into thinking you were safe when this isn't your friend Steve, it's St3vE with a shiv.

You are left constantly on your toes in a thrilling game of cat and mouse as you complete your objectives, each time you learn more about the maps, the AI, the world, and it's a fantastic journey that doesn't pull its punches.

[h2] The future is grim (but bright for us!) [/h2]
With more content on the horizon, our poor characters are bound to face many more horrors in the future. At the time of writing, we've recently recieved a new major area with the court and I'm looking forwards to seeing even more from Red Barrels work. 
It's great fun to just grab some friends and hop in, and if you're alone? Fear not, there are more than enough players looking to party up in the lobbies, and whilst you wait, you might as well challenge some folks there to arm wrestling or chess on the side.

[h3]One of my favourite games from 2023, and easily deserving of your purchase![/h3]

The Outlast Trials has since launch become one of my favorite games of recent times, and it comes to no surprise, considering the huge amount of love and work that's been put into it.

When the AAA gaming industry seems to have run dry on ideas and decided to start milking their previous successful titles with remakes or unnecessary sequels, The Red Barrels have proven how much potential this game has to become an horror experience to last for many years to come and properly justify and promote the Outlast saga legacy.

+ Impressive character and cell (your room) customization.
+ Smart and beautiful level design.
+ High replayabilty.
+ Many unlockables, both cosmetics with in-game currency, and skills with in-game tickets. 
+ Cooperation is rewarded, promoting team gameplay.

Short Version: 

Outlast Trials feels like the best of both worlds for co-op players and solo players providing a Left 4 Dead style of map design and enemy variety. There are plenty of abilities and perks to use that are acquired through gameplay leveling just by doing the trials/quests. With solo gameplay in mind, there is plenty to love as a horror game with a tense atmosphere, decent use of keeping players scared and set of mechanics to challenge players. The only drawbacks are that the game seems to require an online connection, which can dismay those that prefer single player gameplay and that some might find the game getting stale after awhile. Plenty to like with a spine chilling horror atmosphere, might even be arguably better than Outlast 1.

Long Version:

Outlast Trials is the third entry into the Outlast series by Red Barrels and takes place as a prequel from the first Outlast. Instead of taking control of a character, players are given the option to create their own character with a set of cosmetic choices. Neat. After that, players will be put into a Prologue to set the stage. Personally, I do not like games that do not let players set options before starting any gameplay. Just from the gameplay, it's easy to ease into the horror atmosphere; which is designed and modeled to near perfection with the Unreal Engine, just as good as Outlast 1. The gameplay is pretty similar to the first two games minus a camera being the source of a night vision point of view. Differences come down to the unique abilities players can equip to stun attackers, see through walls with x-ray, blind enemies, and heal your teammates. With a full team of 4 people, there's a lot to be able to pull off in co-op. Veterans of the Outlast series might be deterred by the co-op option but it's not required, there is a solo option for them. Some mechanics are changed out such as doppelgangers of teammates are not present in solo (Which is a dirty trick in co-op lol). It's more difficult in solo but it is possible to complete a trial to gain exp or cosmetics that are not locked behind a paywall......yet. Always be cautiously aware of that especially with Early Access titles such as this. There is a argument to make where Outlast Trials is a far better horror game than Outlast 1 and 2. Trials relies on RNG horror events to trigger plus mechanics that require players to use dark areas to hide (Or light with some enemies using night vision), the start of every trial however does a predictable jumpscare flash and it got old REALLY quick, removing it would change nothing as it's there purely for reactions. Back to the gameplay, there is a level system that allows players to upgrade their abilities or acquire perks that can change the game slightly or greatly. The maps are very similar to Left 4 Dead as the current trials present have subtle variations that either block doors, remove hiding spots, limit items, or add enemies so experiences might change in-between each trial. I can imagine people might find the same maps stale after awhile, a test of time so to speak. Left 4 Dead and Payday 2 maps haven't gotten old so there might be some lightning in a bottle somewhere in map design for Outlast Trials too. We'll see, this is an Early Access title so please bear that in mind as content is a mystery before making a purchase. When you start the game, you'll see 3 maps with one locked marked as Season One, it is playable after completing every trial but seeing 'Season One' does make me wonder if a Battle Pass is on the horizon. Caution to the wind, as the saying goes.

Update: So far, there is no battle pass. Different challenges are presented in currently existing maps with a big update that added some useless perks and some great perks and abilities. Not much has changed, but the game is still worth it. The 'endings' to the 'story' are pointless so don't mind the story potential as I can't get motivated into exploring it as it just does the same problems that hindered Outlast 2's story.

If I had to give Outlast Trials a grade, I would give an B-

[h1] Almost as good as the first game [/h1]
    This is coming from someone who as played every entry in the Outlast games, including on the highest difficulties.
I never really find horror games that scary and I play them for the anticipation and atmosphere that the developers created. Outlast was an exception and it was genuinely terrifying only being able to rely on your camcorder, reading Miles cynical monologue. The Outlast Trials keeps the same gameplay as the previous games: running and hiding from psychotic people while trying to escape. 
Your main goal is to complete objectives for the Murkoff Corporation to test out their therapy techniques, and only then will you be able to earn your freedom. These are split into Programs, which have one long trial and two challenges. There are also two harder versions of the trial.


[h1] The Good [/h1]
    The only hope of defending yourself is to hide. The stealth from the last couple of games has been improved with the ability to throw objects to quickly stun or distract enemies. Other than than you can hide in plain sight in the dark because most enemies can't see you in the dark like other games which is really cool.
The atmosphere, which is really important for me, is really interesting and reminds me of the first game, as I was a fan of the asylum environment than the outdoor one from the second game. (hopefully we see something like this in this game soon) As a personal bias, I didn't really find this game scary, however I don't really find horror games scary, but this game was excellent at stressing me the fuck out and I applaud Red Barrel at making a good horror game once again that focuses on the psychological aspect rather than cheap jumpcares. There are jumpscares in the sense that you will be caught off guard while doing objectives and its not a bad thing at all.

[h1] The Bad? [/h1]
    So far my only criticism is the small amount of content currently available for most people. I've have 100% completed the first game and it's DLC, and the second game, so I have a lot of experience and in my opinion, the game is decently balanced while solo, and generally easy from a multiplayer perspective. This changes as you scale up to Program X. A lot of the hard missions are fun for the most part, but for most people its really difficult.
This game doesn't have as much story content as the previous entries because it is primarily a multiplayer focused game and may be off-putting for solo players because most of the "end game" content so far is just harder versions of previous trials and challenges.

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
    As of right now, the game is worth getting if you plan on playing it as a multiplayer game, with friends or with random people. Regardless of who, its a fun and chaotic, and sometimes scary. If you want to play this game solo, I'd wait for a sale or until more content because as of now it may be a little too repetitive for how little story content there is. You will be getting the same game-play experience as a typical Outlast game but without the story which will only get better with more updates coming to the game.

Have you ever wanted to be tortured by the CIA, but have been met with the grim reality that they stopped doing that (to our knowledge) after the Cold War ended? Fret not, outlast trials will scratch that itch.

I have always been a fan of Outlast in general; But I have been looking forward to this particular release as it was cooperative. The whole premise of the game was quite intriguing and was most definitely enjoyable to play. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Outlast and/or those that are looking for something that is leaned towards suspense puzzle solving. This game is also quite fun to play alongside others.

The overall story of Outlast Trials is not the most spectacular aspect of the game. Regardless, I enjoy and appreciate the lore surrounding the series, but I know most players aren't playing this game for the story. 

Trials can be played alone or with up to four people. Players are transported to a PVE environment (5 maps as of now-- the final map is exclusively singleplayer) with a handful of enemies, at the moment, the enemy variation is pretty sparse, but the randomness of where they spawn keeps things interesting for the most part. Gameplay focuses on performing a handful of morbid tasks, sneaking around, hiding, inventory management, and a bit of quick thinking. There aren't a lot of different maps right now, but the game does have variants of the available maps to mix things up and open up parts of the map that you would otherwise miss if you only play the default. 

The main mechanics of the game revolve around skills and perks. There are two types of skills, aka Upgrades (Prescriptions and Rigs) to unlock. Prescriptions are passive and Rigs are active. The Prescriptions have to do with stamina, health regen, being able to slide (a must have) and that sort of stuff--while the Rigs have to be activated manually and revolve around stunning enemies, enemy detection, and healing. Meanwhile there are also perks that need to be activated, you can have up to three active perks that can help you move quicker, retaliate more accurately, or be stealthier. 

I started playing the game a few weeks after it was released on Early Access and have been having so much fun with it. There are mini-games that you can play with other players whether or not they're part of your party. Originally, they had two tables dedicated to arm wrestling but in October they added 5-minute chess and 10-minute chess-- I've never had more fun playing chess with friends. So far my favorite non-gameplay related aspects of the game are the character customization and room customization. These small bits of personalization gives the game a touch of hygge despite its contents.

The outlast trials is a game that was suggested to me by friends. With myself not ever playing the original outlast games, I had no idea what to expect.
The Outlast trials for the short time I've played the game was an instantaneous favourite game. Personally, I don't overly enjoy first person horror games but the addition of multiplayer gave the gave a goofy style type of play. I can just remember the times when an AI was chasing myself and my friend down a corridor and I would close and lock my friend out of a room. The game has a fair amount of problems however and this has already caused a dramatic fall in player count. Problems such as AI characters becoming stuck on walls whilst in a chase with you or them camping your only way out, it kind of removes the scary "how am I going to escape" aspect. Another problem is the rate the developers are adding new content and trials (maps). In my 9 hours of game play, I managed to complete the full two series of trials and play some of them again. If the developers don't start adding more content, the game will continue to decline..

My overall rating for this game is 7.5/10

This game is a niche horror experience, or a fun time with your friends. Or both, run away screaming past your friend as they get stabbed by a mentally ill man with a machete (seriously, who keeps giving them machetes...?) The AI is actually competent and they have good designs!
It's also a cool game to just play on your own if you're up for it, sure it may be slightly more difficult if you don't really know what you're doing, compared to not knowing what to do with friends, but once you get the gist of the game you'll like it.
The only downside to that is it gets a bit repetitive once you've done everything a lot more times over and through, but each time you load up a trial it randomizes blocked/locked doors, cabinets (mechanical and medicinal), and sound traps. So it adds some fresh variety.

Overall really cool game, I've played it a ton, made me love the rest of the Outlast series.

The Outlast Trials place players into a myriad of situations and areas within which they are meant to fulfill their goals and then return to the home base. This is a fine start, but the problems arise for the single player when you find yourself being subjected to some of the restraints and restrictions of this being treated as an online multiplayer game:

1. You are restricted to three lives per therapy session, and you can't quit the game and resume a session from where you left off.
2. You cannot pause the game, even when playing alone. If players could join an ongoing game of their own accord with your input, this would make perfect sense, but not allowing players playing completely solo to pause a horror game seems a bit iffy to me.
3. If a player is idle for too long, they will be booted from the game, regardless of how much progress they've made and whether or not they were playing alone. Again, this is a decision that makes perfect sense for an online game, but considering you already can't pause the game and are on limited lives, this seems extra punishing for solo players. I found myself needing to step away to walk my dog, only to find myself having been booted to the main menu when I return with nothing to show for the hour of gameplay I'd engaged in up to that point.
4. When you are booted from the game this way, you don't gain any experience or rewards like you would have if your character simply died and ran out of lives. Again, this is a design choice that makes sense for the online aspect of the game: why reward players who were potentially dragging down their partners? On the other hand, one could argue a player who was playing alone is already being punished by the game enough by losing all of their progress.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

While it may seem to lack content on the surface, the game is very re-playable. Not just in the sense of playing the same level over again, but with who you play with. If you play by yourself, it's tense and stressful, you're constantly running, the outlast experience you know and love. On the other hand, in my experience, playing with a full squad makes the game hilarious, cause you hear people screaming, all the while you're trying to coordinate with everyone to get the objective done. It's chaotic, but that's what makes it so fun.
Even better when you play as Bill Murray

[b][u]The Outlast Trials[/u][/b] does everything right and near-perfectly in a survival horror game.

There is permanent progression through level-ups, skill and customization unlocks, which incentivises players to continue playing long after they've completed the final stage.

Regular content updates such as new challenges, trials, maps and monsters encourage players to return often to experience something new.

Players are weak, but not defenceless. Bricks, bottles and Rigs let players buy precious time to avoid enemies or slow them down. This rewards a more aggressive play-style compared to most horror games which rely too heavily on stealth. Due to offensive items, matches don't need to be unnecessarily prolonged and waste time.

Mini-games let players occupy time while waiting for groups to form, players to join and trials to start. They also have ranking systems that give a sense of accomplishment, so players can treat these side activities just as seriously as the main game itself.

Customization for characters and their cells give players the chance to display their visual flair and personality without the need for words. Want to show that you're a wannabe serial killer? Dress in the skin of your victims and display their body parts in your blood-drenched room. There are hundreds of individual items to unlock and buy and more are frequently added.

Players can choose how accessible or immersive they want their game to be played. Show or hide all HUDs and indicators, or choose from a mix. You can feel more in control or feel more helpless depending on how much info you are willing to see on your HUD.

Enemy designs are creative and each enemy character has a distinct personality, from the small grunts to the large ones and the prime assets which are the ultimate villains, each the centerpiece of their particular program. When enemies grab, beat, choke and toss you around, the first-person perspective puts you into the action and you feel absolute terror and fear.

Sounds in the game are eerie, especially when you hear distant screams and nearby mumbling from unknown sources. Is it simply your imagination, or are there enemies lurking close by where you can't see them? The senseless ranting and menacing monologues by the enemies tell you there is no reasoning with them- you must flee or die. Every movement and motion has an impact, because sound is also crucial to the gameplay and scoring.

The visuals are incredible. Everything is visceral and realistic, to the point where the player feels truly immersed in each location. The bloody set pieces and makeshift infrastructure show much attention to detail and every prop is well-placed and tells a small story in the overall setting. Spend time appreciating how objects are placed, why they are placed there, and you can see how each prop fits into the lore of each program perfectly. From the scratched writing on the wall, to how the mannequins are violated and posed, the player can almost perceive the madness of the world from the antagonists' minds.

A well-optimized game that runs at consistent and high frame-rates even on lower-end PCs at maxed settings. Lots of settings to configure graphics, interfaces, volume and regional servers. Server disconnections or interruptions are as rare as to be almost non-existent, and I've only been disconnected twice- that was on launch day itself.

A must-play game for all fans of survival horror, whether you intend to play solo or with others.
Outlast Trials my beloved <3

I thought after 90 hours of playtime I owed this game a new review, so here we are. My initial thoughts of this game were clouded heavily by my love for the first game and it's DLC; this the intro mission to this game not really hitting the same vibes in the same way as they both did. 90 hours in...well I'd say that the vibe still doesn't hit the same, but that doesn't stop the game from being enjoyable and a hell of a lot of fun with friends.

Outlast Trials for me fails to capture the terrifying atmosphere, the tension and the complete powerlessness that you feel when walking around in the first two games; so as an Outlast title, I feel as though Outlast Trials falls flat in this area. The game however does excel completely when it comes to artistic design, map creation, character development, lore and it's multiplayer aspects. The trials have been thoroughly enjoyable both to tackle on a solo run or with a group of friends.

For an early access game this is polished; and at first glance you might even think it's a completed title...even when it isn't. The content currently in the game will keep you occupied and wanting to continue playing for hours; and there is still more content promised for future updates, during early access leading up to the final game release (although I'm not sure how frequent updates will be). With a few more maps, characters and a whole bunch of lore and maybe even collectables added, this game has so much potential. I'm really excited to see where the developers are planning on taking the game as it moves forward.

The only cons I have with the game in it's current state are the psychosis affect; it gives me incredibly bad motion sickness because of the way the camera moves. Maybe there could be an accessibility toggle or it could be changed altogether to something else. The other con I have is that honestly the game isn't dark enough. Which sounds dumb but when I think of the original games they were dark, and terrifying, it made navigating so difficult; these maps in comparison are so bright it's hard to feel scared at all.

7.5/10

I've played every Scenario and MK challenge with my Homies about 10Hrs in, and I like this game, I have some complaints doe. 

First of all the Gameplay, the Graphics, and the Controls are spot on, they feel like an Outlast game and play Exactly like that, it's also Smooth as hell, tho I would not Recommend Ray tracing, I had it enabled at Launch and it crashed my Game, after Update #1 I tried it again and had 20Fps, with a 3070 TI, that's not supposed to happen. 

Now at the Current state, you have 3 Unique Scenarios, with Project X and Project Omega just being recycled and harder versions of those scenarios, making for some people that can't get enough more and harder Content. This brings me to the issue of the game, it is sadly not Scary, rather the game does not focus on horror at all and just on Replay ability and Fun, now some things can catch u Off guard like the Fake players (which are well made and fool you, even tho they can see you everywhere even in the dark, so there kinda stronger than the normal enemies)

The 3 Scenarios or Trials are good, with the first 2 (Police Station and Carnival) having a nice theme and cool design, but it already stops at that because the third scenario (Cult/Church idk) already starts Reusing ideas, like the Children and the mother which were already present in the Carnival scenario, the game has also some MK Challenges which are 30-40 min little adventures ig you do in the about same/little difference areas of the Trials, as I said I played all those. This made the game's replayability suffer imo as we were already a bit unmotivated after the church scenario was so close-themed like the Carnival scenario.

The Main hub is also well made, cosmetic items that drop from trials can be used to change the style of yourself and your room, so u can pump up your crip (I love that ), its also cool that different characters upgrade your Rig or give you permanent upgrades to your character. The coolest feature of the Hub is the arm wrestling, It's just a fun Dead by Daylight Style QTE Minigame against someone else, simple but effective, love that. 

the Different gameplay mechanics, all fit well, the rigs make for nice change and coordination and different playstyles, these are all great, even tho I think the hiding psychos and the doc that just spawns randomly at a door that alarms like 3 seconds before that, is hard to avoid and needs improvement.

The Foundations of this game are Great, now it just needs the Content to Support it, and because of the lack of content 30€ is a bit Harsh, if it gets more content I'm happy to give it a better review. For now 6.5/10

Basically Outlast as online co-op with quite short and simple scenarios (maps) to run through, either solo or with up to four friends. You can quickly find a group of four players and hop into a match, easy to pick up and play. Finally a real competitor for Dead by Daylight, and with actual integrated online voice-chat!

Matchmaking works quite nicely already, experienced a couple small bugs with players getting stuck in shuttles when loading into a match. But hey, as of writing it's still in early access. Game performance has vastly improved when compared to the closed beta days. Haven't experienced any crashes either.

For the current price, would highly recommend if you enjoy horror-themed online co-op games with PvE (and arm wrestling).

Outlast trials is a co-op multiplayer game where up to 4 players can play mission based trials that involve executing snitches, grinding children, or being forced to play amusement park games to earn tickets to freedom. 

While there isn’t a full story like the previous outlast games there is a short  story told through the mission that you have to compete .The introduction also has a short story of how you ended up on the trials to begin with. Inside the missions you will also find evidence folders that contain more lure to give you more insight on the project you are being used for.

Inside the mission you will be met with various tasks of finding keys, powering generators, looking for missing ingredients, disabling gates and doors, killing key targets, hacking off limbs, and a variety of other things.
You will be chased by enemies who can stab you, punch you, infect you with gas that causes you to go mental, electrocute you, and a sock puppet thay will drill through your face. There really no end to the multiple ways you can die here, and almost all the enemies can execute you so you will need a revive to continue playing.

Each map is very large and takes about 30min or longer to complete the first time. Each map has different missions to choose and each has their own layout of that map so you aren’t seeing the same area for 5 different missions. It’s very well done how they keep things familiar but make it different.

When not playing trials you are placed into the hub which is like a prison block where you can decorate your room and level up skills to your character and set different optional skills and offensive tools depending on your play style like healing or placing traps to slow or blind enemies.

So far this game is extremely good and does what it does well while keeping you on the move for fast paced horror action or slow stealthy sneaking.

I played this on steam deck and the game is very optimized and maintains 50-60fps all the time with ultra textures and medium everything else using FSR 2

[b]Wow, just wow Red Barrels can't miss can they[/b]

• Absolutely blown away by how fun and smooth it plays it does not feel like an Early Access game what so ever feels more of a complete game than Jedi: Survivor and that's saying something.

• 4-Hours in and I only have good things to say, the universe they built is one of a kind, grimmy, dark and specially gory I love Red Barrels for going all in and not holding back when it comes to art direction.

• The CO-OP gameplay just works and plays amazingly and to think this is their first ever Multiplayer/Online game is crazy. they've nailed the things that make a CO-OP game unique and fun, even playing with randoms that don't really cooperate still feels like they cooperate if that makes any sense. 

• Not introducing any kind of MTX is a big win also, I can only see this game blooming from here on out. Red Barrels is yet to disappoint. the future is very bright and has big potential and I'm all for it!

I bought this game when it first came out liked it but I didnt love it. I thought compared to the other installments in the franchise this one was lacking in overall story.  This game is not a linear story like the other games. It doesnt require you to keep playing for long periods of time to gain progress. Red Barrels has done something wonderful with this game. The stories in this game are crafted well and tightly packed in small vignettes. I think as life has gotten busier for me this sort of horror game really suits my time while still giving me little jumpscares. The Coop feature is also quite nice as it gives my buddies and I something else to play other than the usual suspects. This game is still in beta but from beginning to now Ive seen the events they have put in + the new trial; so far this game has been very promising. Its still in early access but so far this studio has delivered (there's always a need for more content). I think for $30 or less you will definitely be able to find value in this game.

Overall lovely multiplayer experience. Haven't had much experience playing solo, however I heard it scales for you in difficulty. My only gripe is how some challenges in the higher difficulties seem a bit cheap. There are these guys that mimic other players, and if you're near them they'll pull out a knife and stab you. You would think the challenge would be to identify who's a real player and who's the imposter, however in the later difficulties it seems more of a cheap way to knock your grade down if you're surrounded by multiple enemies- because they will walk straight over to you and stab. Overall it's a multiplayer game, so sometimes things can seem cheap/bullshit when in reality it's not, however I do genuinely think difficulty scaling leans towards throwing more enemies at you instead of providing a real challenge. You end up frustrated, and the overall fear factor fades much quicker that way than it normally would from multiple playthroughs.

One of the standout features of The Outlast Trials is its seamless integration of cooperative gameplay into the horror narrative. The game allows players to team up with friends or strangers online, creating an intense and nerve-wracking experience as you navigate the nightmarish Cold War-era environment together. The cooperative aspect adds an extra dimension to the horror, as you must rely on your teammates to survive the relentless onslaught of terror.

Visually, The Outlast Trials is a stunning masterpiece. The developers have meticulously crafted a chilling atmosphere that immerses players in the eerie, Cold War-era setting. The detailed environments, ominous lighting, and spine-chilling sound design contribute to a palpable sense of dread, ensuring that every corner turned is fraught with tension. The graphics are not only a feast for the eyes but also an integral part of the overall horror experience.

The narrative in The Outlast Trials is another strong point. While it maintains the psychological horror elements that the series is known for, the addition of cooperative play introduces new dynamics to the storytelling. The game delves into the mysterious experiments conducted in the Murkoff Corporation's facility, creating a captivating and suspenseful plot that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

The gameplay mechanics are intuitive and responsive, allowing for a seamless cooperative experience. The Outlast Trials retains the heart-pounding stealth elements and resource management that fans of the series love, while also introducing new challenges that require teamwork to overcome. The variety of enemies and unpredictable events ensure that each playthrough is a unique and adrenaline-fueled adventure.

In conclusion, The Outlast Trials is a triumph in the horror gaming genre. It successfully builds upon the foundation laid by its predecessors, introducing a cooperative element that elevates the fear factor to new heights. With its exceptional visuals, gripping narrative, and immersive gameplay, The Outlast Trials is a must-play for horror enthusiasts and a testament to Red Barrels' mastery in crafting unforgettable gaming experiences. Brace yourself for a relentless journey into the heart of fear, where survival depends on the strength of your alliances and the resilience of your nerves.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Felt like a steep learning curve at first, but once I got the mechanics down and a few upgrades, I've been having a hard time putting it down. One of the few games that's fun in multiplayer without needing a mic either.

Great continuation of the Outlast formula, takes what made 1 and 2 interesting, combines them and adds proper gameplay and reasons to engage with the stealth. Along with fixing some issues people had with 2's writing.

Basically? Gameplay-wise It's Outlast but how you thought it played watching some youtuber scream their lungs out at the funny naked men. Sound especially plays a big role with there being various traps and things in the environment which can give away your position, coupled with a whole cast of funny specialized variants who are out for your blood.

My only real complaint would be how unlocking cosmetics is handled - grinding for them can definitely get really tedious if there's a specific outfit you want, otherwise you just sorta gotta make do with what you're given, and having to replay a mission tons of times for a single outfit you might not even get can get really frustrating I bet.

Oh, and some missing content from the closed beta (specifically peeking around doors when opening them, less this is part of the second pharmacist upgrade tree)

Also, please re-add the ability to holster items! I do like the option for auto hiding but personally pressing X to hide the item manually was more intuitive in my opinion. Along with making it so you don't accidentally use an item.

Regardless, that's really my only set of criticisms, i'm glad to see the game is really polished as well despite being in EA, coupled with having some really good optimization, which is a trend I'm happy to see Red Barrels stick to after all this time.

Definitely really excited to see where this goes over the coming months/years.

Halloween update thoughts: (10/31/2023)
Pretty neat update all around! New trial is spiffy, I liked the acid mechanic, real neat.
A lot of the unused cosmetics datamined from the closed beta have been finally added, plus some new ones which are super neat to see.

I think Trials is in an ideal state to be enjoyed, however there are some slight annoyances I have:

New MK trials are fine, but have some issues:

The halloween  NV goggles don't change the night vision color! I feel like that'd be a really cool effect to aim for in the future, especially since you're in the dark a lot - and the different color would really help make the goggles feel more important and worth it in the end.

Free the prisoners is an absolute joke in singleplayer, I'm not sure if it's better in multiplayer but it deadass feels like cut content hastily slapped together. All you have to do is get the key and make it to the center room, press the button and then get out.
It took me around four minutes to do my first go, which is whack.

Feels like one designed for grinding rather than a substantial MK trial addition.

Orphan abduction one is definitely better, I don't really have any complaints, it's a nice little addition which changes up the design of the orphanage's interior to feel different and fresh enough.

I have yet to do Drill the futterman.

I wouldn't exactly mind these if Vindicate The Guilty(tm) actually had MK challenges of its own, and the other three were added to the previous trials (I doubt anyone would complain.) but it lacks any unique ones using the courthouse map, which is quite strange-

Weirder enough is the acid bucket mechanic - that could really make for an interesting mk-challenge focused scenario, since I always saw the mk-challenges as focusing specifically on elements from the main trials in bite-sized pieces which were quick and more focused.

Vindicate the guilty has none of that, so I am curious if these new ones were rushed out, potentially?
I don't think they're bad, just a tad bit underwhelming.

Otherwise? I think the update is quite good! Hopefully we get a christmas update to follow - however game design is difficult and a pain in the ass, especially with what Red Barrels is trying to make and maintain. I'm willing to be patient and trust that RB knows what the hell they're doing.

Don't crunch your employees uwu, do your best and we'll wait patiently.

Trials isn't a live service experience - it's an early access game.

🎀At times boring, some maps confusing and even too punitive, a huge waste of useless time wandering around in vain looking for things and ways out.
The night vision is the worst part, too painful for my eyes because the white light emitted is too strong, especially when I end up in illuminated areas it is even worse and I am literally blinded, rather than adding a green filter which would have been less invasive and much lighter.
I guess the developers didn't try to play it for several hours, otherwise they would have realized the huge mess.

🎀Initially it was quite interesting, it seemed like something different, it really isn't.
After just 35 hours it became very repetitive and boring, just like other similar games.
The mechanics are all the same regardless of what you have to do in different missions.
Did I say different missions?
Oops, my mistake, there is absolutely nothing different.
All comes down to searching for the same objects to complete the mission and escape.
The perks to unlock or upgrade are only useful to make things easier for you or the other players in the party, obviously, but they don't change anything in terms of fun.
The labels on the store page are wrong, the game has nothing horror at all it's just a link to the world of Outlast, unless someone gets scared by a bunch of funny pixels, rather than horrible enemies.
Technically it's done well but this title really offers very little for an online version that should try to entertain the players for a long time.
Gameplay aside, but with the problem of the white light emitted by the night vision device, it is unplayable for me.

🎀I don't know, but for me it's years of development thrown in the trash.
A horror series turned into an action game.
Search, run, hide, finished!
Without even a shred of history, only mentions found on pieces of paper scattered around.
The game is still in early access, the price is very low, there is content to come, probably new maps.
Bored after only 35 hours, for an online game it's really too little and it's not a good sign.
I would have preferred a normal single player.

🎀In development for years to find a castrated gameplay, an incomplete game with only one mechanic, apart from the maps and different difficulties, in addition to the fact that users feedback is asked for development, which to me seems to be synonymous with lack of ideas on further development.

At the moment, source SteamDB Dead by Daylight exceeds 37,000 players online, while Outlast only has 2,200, there must be a reason.

🎀Should I recommend it?
I really would like to, but I don't feel like deceiving anyone, you can always try it and at the latest ask for a refund within 2 hours.

I was expecting - honestly - Outlast trials to not be as scary as the first two games given its multiplayer component. It turns out on the one hand that the fact of playing the game with someone else does not make it less scary even though playing in singleplayer provides an unrivalled feeling of heart-crushing abandonment that can't be replicated by the presence of a second reagent. The sleep room on the other hand is not as convincing and it keeps me from reaching the levels of fear I experienced playing Outlast 1 & 2. More on that below.

The graphics are properly incapacitating sometimes. The level of detail as well as the care going into the crafting of these different biomes - prime assets characters included - are astonishing, borderline insane more often than not while still being early access. The mere fact that all of the events take place in gigantic warehouses turned into joyous psycho-horror-fu*kfest movie studios makes it even more stunningly frightening and beautifully disturbing. This game's artistic patte is a masterful take on how graphics can be used to enhance fear and deepen the sense of danger in a horror game.

The Trials as well as the submissions can all be completed in solo as well as in multiplayer. My experience involves both types of gameplay and I'm really impressed by Red Barrels for bending the rules as well as the interactions with the surroundings according to how many reagents tackle the trials. The randomisation of the state of doors as well as the spawning of traps is another brilliant way to add replayability. Exploring the concept of being a guinea pig experienced on alive is a fantastic idea to give more insight into Murkoff's agenda and background. A perfect excuse to flesh out the lore.

I know the game can be played solo but it sells itself more or less as a live-coop game, and that's where the itch becomes the scratch for me because it takes away one CORE component that the first two games exemplified to an indecent degree, far more than any other game before : loneliness. I know you have Silent Hill, SOMA, Amnesia, Resident Evil Rebirth but loneliness in Outlast feels like the main antagonist because there's nothing more terrifying than being hunted alive by crazed psychos completely unbeknownst to the rest of the world, knowing nobody can hear you or save you. Then kicks in the lack of respite coupled to the lack of safety, keeping you alert because you have no idea when the next atrocity will hit, nor how. As a player, that gives horror a entirely new dimension. As said by the first Outlast, your only choices are to run, hide or die. Straightforward. That means you're gonna suffer.

In Trials, it's toned down mainly because of the sleep room. That's how I feel about it.
It's a beautifully crafted interlude between two trials and it gives lore, but it takes too much of the scare factor away with it. Outlast's safe havens (maybe heavens here) have always had that phenomenal particularity that whilst they could be devoid of enemies they never brought down the level of scare, because sound fx kept you on edge (be it music or scary winds, creaking planks, etc...).

The sleep room almost feels like my house. It's white, clean as f*ck, full of questionable looking items that make the bulk of the decoration and I've got my own sleep room. I even laugh when I see other reagent's sleep cells and realise they've got even shi**ier decoration tastes than I do. That's the fun part but to be honest, the problem I've got with it is that I feel too detached from the survival-horror experience I enlisted for when roaming the sleep room and the fact that I can socialise is actually my biggest complaint. Seeing other reagents controlled by real people is an immersion breaker when it comes to horror. I wish the singleplayer component was actually separate from the constantly-buzzing-social-hub-tailored experience should the player so wishes. The sleep room has tons of features to fall for but that social component - knowing there are other real humans with you  instead of quicksilver reagents - takes all the unique and defining scare-worthy component Outlast patte away. It dispels the fear of the unknown because there's no way you can get in danger in the sleep room. It's too mentally comfortable. Some people will hallucinate reading this comment I'm sure, but I signed for an Outlast game, a digital entity known for pushing the boundaries of horror in many ways and so far I've yet to experience what Outlast 1 & 2 made me go through.

I wish that I was given the full solo route option by replacing the other players with NPC reagents (nice potential extra lore here) suffering through their therapy in their own unique way (like turning briefly hostile towards me if I beat them at arm-wrestling or go in their room and they spot me for example) so I can feel forsaken and left on my own to rot in my cell contemplating the failure of my last trial F Grade because I got ra*ed and face-grated by a terrifying boll*cks-hanging grunt while knowing that the only way for me to get rid of all this is to delve back into that nightmarish trial and face my demons. In the first two Outlast games, if you sh*t yourself, no f*cks were given. Deal with the terror and inch forward or digitally die and leave. Run, hide or die situations everywhere from beginning to the end. No respite.

Can terror-lovers get this please RED Barrels *_*?

Exceptional level and sound design, careful use of prime assets and wonderful replayability safeguarded by the randomised placement of assets, items and traps. make The Outlast Trials the epitome of mechanical efficiency and matured gameplay in many ways.

As a fan of the saga, I'm loving so far the game. You have a lot to do, like really a lot and there will be more when the full game releases although I would like to mention some aspects of the game:
--Staying true to the old games--
1. The vaulting is not as nice as it used to look in the old games, in my opinion the vaulting animation look really bad now, you barely can see your arms and legs and some people like this but as I mentioned earlier it's in my opinion. It would've been better if you could see your character actually vaulting instead of just the camera moving
2. You can now defend yourself which I mean it's fine but in the old games all you could do was run
--Outlast & gameplay--
1. The feeling of playing an OUTLAST GAME some what dissappeared because of this game, I do think I am playing an outlast game, I just don't feel the same vibe as I do with outlast 2 and 1.
2. The game does jumpscare me when I'm catched out of guard, which I like that from the game since I haven't been afraid of a horror game in a long time.
3. You will probably experience this but the enemies might be extremely annoying and bothersome for you, This is my case. Besides some times jumpscaring me I feel really annoyed when I'm interrupted doing something but of course, it's the point of the game and they did a great job on doing so
4. As I mentioned in the previous section, the parkour animations is not so good as I would say like the previous games, if you liked the bouncing camera from the previous games sadly and I'm pretty sure it will not come back, I hope it does though. One of the main reasons why I loved to get into chases in purpose just so I could see the camera wobbling around because it immersed me, I understand some people wouldn't like this and that's perfectly fine, I would like it if they did added it and if people don't like it they just choose the reduce motion sickness option so they can have that view bouncing that is currently in the game
5. Graphics are pretty good, not a massive upgrade from Outlast 2 but they are pretty solid
6. Replayability I'm not so sure but you can check other people's reviews but as far as I've seen, it's got a TON of replayability I think
7. The facility is AMAZING, I love moving around and interacting with other people and I love to walk to some place I need to upgrade something instead of just clicking some buttons which for me it is kinda boring.

In conclusion: The game is good and I'm currently playing it a lot more than any other game I have in my library, it doesn't stay too true to the old games but it's fine because this game differentiates itself from the last couple of games in a good way.

Unironically my favorite 4 player coop game to play with friends since Left 4 Dead 2. Does for Outlast what Resident Evil outbreak essentially did for Resident Evil, but I would go further and state that it probably mechanically speaking has the best gameplay of any outlast game with the most stuff going on mechanics wise. Lots of mechanics here and some of them you just have to learn by playing the game or talking to people and having them teach you and are not straight up explained to you but that just makes me appreciate them that much more. I always thought that the previous games were a little mechanically lacking for my taste and kind of simple so this is very much a treat in my eyes. Also the map design is just good. The singleplayer outlast games felt very linear but here we have maps that are all basically designed around the objective and expanding outward from it rather than the exits which is the superior way to do it IMO and more closely aligns with map design trends from older survival horror games. I think this is my Favorite Outlast game.

I have to write this review because I truly love this game. 60+ hours in and I’m still enjoying every bit of the trials. This type of horror genre is the best genre considering it’s crazy storytelling and backdoor political horror. I won’t spoil anything but wow, the story of the Murkoff Corporation and their experiments to create a different type of ‘weapon’ for the state is just incredible. 

It’s not just about running, hiding and achieving the goals of the trial. It’s about the process of getting perfect in your trial runs and how sharp you have to become after trying over and over again. Like the doctor says after you complete a trial. ‘If I say jump, you jump. But I want you to say.. how high? Can you be my how high?’ These type of quotes describe the intensity of the trials and man, what a masterpiece. 

I’m looking forward to the future development of the Outlast Trials and I have great hope that Red Barrels will become even bigger then they are now, as long as they keep this game updated and start lobbying for an Outlast movie/series. 

Keep up the good work Red Barrels! :)

Single-player still sucks. I got pretty far in the Halloween trials but I got to one where Gooseberry can 1-shot you with 4 bars of damage, got to the end and died and failed. I tried matchmaking, waited 5min to get a group for Halloween trials, only for everyone  to leave after I queued the same trial, leaving me solo. I tried my best but died to Gooseberry again, instantly failing the mission just 2 disarms short of the exit unlocking. WTF happened to having 3 lives? I'm supposed to be at the mercy of AI RNG deciding whether they find me or not and insta-killing me and forcing me out of the whole trial if they do? I get that there's pills now to give you extra lives, but that's created a new problem where if they just don't spawn, you're forced to play in a pseudo-hardcore gamemode where you have 1 life and most of the enemies 1-shot you. I didn't even mention the other modifiers, typically making the enemies faster, more alert, less lenient during chases. The original problem with solo was always how stacked it felt against you. I had a game where there were 5 special enemies constantly hovering around me, there were times where I had to sit in a locker for several minutes because when one guy left another entered the room. The last objective was at the end of a linear hallway that happened to attract 1-2 enemies every time I went to work on it. These types of missions take almost an hour to complete as well, it's such a waste of time. The reason it's so stacked is because the levels are designed with 4 people in mind. So why is it the developers insist on adding extra lives instead of balancing the levels based on player-count by removing a couple enemies, or making their pathing spread wider throughout the map so you bump into them less frequently? Lives and pills will never be a replacement for teamwork and being able to split enemy attention. This game is fun with a friend, and really fun with 3 friends, but I can't recommend it because of how unfair and frustrating the solo experience is.

"Cagate de miedo; El juego." The Outlast: Trials es uno de los pococs juegos triple a modernos en los que consistentemente vas a estar cagado de risa y cagado de miedo al mismo tiempo. Lanzar botellas y ladrillos es la unica forma de defenderse en el juego, y con la frecuencia con la que te persiguen te vas a sentir como un autentico manifestante en el estallido social chileno del 2019. Paco electrico y la ctm, 10/10.

The Outlast Trials takes the fun cat-and-mouse, hide-and-seek, nightvision-fueled gameplay of the original two single player entries of the franchise, and throttles it into a clever multiplayer format while building on some well-welcomed innovations and new mechanics.

Players are thrown together and must work together to survive. Well, they don't have to, but it would be greatly to their detriment. Powerless to fight back (except for the occasional brick or bottle), terrifying NPC enemies will patrol the grounds of the Trials, watching key objectives and keeping you on your toes. It's up to you and your team to use your wits, surroundings, and crucial teamwork to lure enemies away from key objectives while solving puzzles/completing these objectives at the same time.

The game, in my opinion, is best experienced and discovered freshly and for the first time with friends who are also discovering it for the first time.

Considering the game cannot be as cinematic as the single player experiences by sheer nature of being multiplayer, this game's AI does an incredible job of facilitating fun chases, as assailants will weave in and out of rooms, and naturally coerce players into leading enemies to each other, creating a terrifying domino effect. The game's proximity chat is an absolute blast, and playing with friends or strangers while being chased and bumping into each other through the winding halls of Murkoff is hilarious and fun with incredible acoustics and quality.

The game experience, especially the UI, has been optimized for casual gameplay, but the game allows for incredible experience customization - allowing you to flip as many switches as possible to tailor the experience how you want. For longtime fans of the franchise, or for players looking for a true scare, Immersive presets are available; on the opposite end of the spectrum, accessible settings allow players to have as much information as needed on screen for a good playing experience.

The Outlast Trials provides me with an extensive gameplay experience, offering multiple hours of immersive entertainment. What truly sets it apart is the spine-tingling sensation it delivers every time I encounter psychosis and face that pesky man leaping towards me >:(. This game brilliantly highlights the immense passion and craftsmanship invested by its developers.

Furthermore, the option to play independently or alongside friends or even with strangers is a feature that I greatly appreciate. This adds a remarkable level of flexibility, and seamlessly adapts to your chosen mode of play.

A noteworthy aspect of this game that deserves applause is the absence of any intrusive microtransactions. This means you can fully engage without constant prompts to make additional purchases, allowing you to immerse yourself in its world without interruption or financial pressure.

Anyway, fun with friends, worth it with a discount.

I've been considering writing a review for this game for months, but never quiet had words that would do it justice.
I'm an old survival horror fan, like I played the first Silent Hill when it came out kind of old.
I loved the first two Outlast games and was very cranky and skeptical of Outlast, or any survival horror, in a multiplayer format. I was happily proven wrong by the Trials.
I play this on solo more than multiplayer and when you play solo, the game takes that into consideration and caters your experience accordingly, I hope it remains that way with future updates.
It's simply a masterpiece, extremely well crafted and thought out. With limited content released, since it was only in Early Access, it still managed to keep my hooked and playing daily since May of 2023. It's replay value is ridiculously good, it's just so much fun.
I highly recommend this for solo or multi-players, I've also been playing it on the Steam Deck and it works flawlessly. Very well crafted in every aspect there is, from music and sound design, all the way to game play and plotting.

If you liked the other games in the Outlast series, you will probably enjoy Trials.

I'll admit I was sceptical when I heard that a series known for its cinematic found-footage formula was going to venture into the co-op multiplayer genre. Startling, however, the result is mostly true to the previous entries, and does an excellent job of making a co-op horror game that can house some really thrilling moments. 

Whilst content has been slow, the content and changes have been good content that truly massively improved the game, its balance, and player experiences for both singleplayer and multiplayer. 

It may not be perfect, but this game is worth your money and time, especially if you have some friends to share it with.

Game is a major RNG grind with minor jump scares and hit boxes that seem to be wider than my waist line (which is impressive) Unnecessary nudity, adult language, suggestive themes; but lets be honest that's part of the reason you are here to play it anyways. If you just plan to play very casually with friends, this game is good. If you plan to play solo though, and want to speed run or improve upon your own scores, forget it. There is not a restart button. There are "multiple lives" now that let you resume the game. This is not a fix since using these penalize you, which shows how stubborn devs are in not allowing a restart button to be present. Actually restarting (backing out, being called a dumbfuck for one minute, going to the terminal, waiting 20 seconds, and going through the dumbass cutscene for one minute) takes two to three minutes at least. Also no offline mode. Even in single player you cannot pause. Not having a basic FUNCTION such as a restart or pause button is embarrassing. It's not even a matter of a feature, because calling a restart button or pause button a feature is like saying a settings menu is a feature. It's a function. A function that should be EXPECTED to exist. The devs have said a restart button "takes away from the intensity" but this is incorrect. Not having a restart and pause button "takes away from the intensity" because the player should just refund and/or uninstall the game. Do better.

Every negative review I've seen on this game is just a terrible take, all of which can be boiled down to either not having friends or not having friends you enjoy. This game is not meant to be a completely immersive horror story, though the elements are there if you look for them. This game is meant to increase the amount of fun that you already experience in a group, as you run yelling and screaming from insane doctors, police, and naked people.

If you go into this game solo expecting the type of gameplay that is engaging to solo play, you are not going to have fun. If you go into it with three more people that you already play games with often, you are probably going to have the time of your life.

As for the gameplay itself, very good. The only things I would want to be different are a mode where the enemies can hear you talk to eachother. And if I don't see Whitehorn in the next trial I'm starting a riot.

Honestly one of the best co-op horror games out there right. The gameplay is a mix of stealth and puzzle solving like most survival horror experiences, however this one shines with its thought provoking narrative. Its also highly repayable especially with different party sizes. Different group sizes will require different strategies based on the map. Weighing the pros and cons of staying together vs splitting up is definitely part of the fun. I also personally LOVE all the body horror in the game. Without spoiling too much, killing the judge and cutting off the legs of jesus christ are top tier moments for this game.

My biggest (and pretty much only) complaint though is the lack of communication from the devs. Ive been playing since the player test last november and i can confidently say this team is known for going radio silent for months at a time. That said, the content has always been worth the wait. It just sucks not knowing whats coming up.

Got it yesterday. Ended up playing for 5 hours with my girlfriend. Playing alone definitely provides a great horror experience. Playing with friends is less stressful and at times funny. Game pretty much seems like what "Blackout Club" was trying to become over time before it was abandoned. There isnt a ton of content yet... Though after 5 hours I still havent beat every mission. The way the missions are designed, there are 4 Levels/Areas and each of those have 4 or 5 missions in them which change up the objectives and goals in game. A really cool feature that we loved is that we get our own Prison Cell / Bedroom in the lobby, which you can decorate and design, as well as unlock lots of cosmetics for your character. Theres nice perks and abilities to buy as well. Other players can visit your room. A great part of the game is that there is text quick chats, so a mic isnt absolutely necessary like in phasmophobia and other popular horror multiplayer games. As well, there is of course voice chat if you prefer talking. The maps are great designed, it pays homage to the original outlast games, the enemies are great, etc. If games like World War Z were too repetitive with not enough missions for you, you might experience that here. While i havent finished everything yet, I can definitely see the point where missions just being overly repetitive will come, so hopefully the developers continue to add new maps, missions, objectives etc. Worth the price though, thats for sure.

I mostly played this with friends, and I've gotta say that the challenges this game provides can bring about some fun (albeit frustrating) trials.

Like in the previous Outlast games, you need to go to point A and retrieve stuff while simultaneously trying to avoid killers. That changes a little bit here. Think of the SAW movies, and then mix it into a kind of gameshow-esque kinda setting. It even brought back its charming weirdness, like full-on public nudity. Penises are abound here, along with decaying tits stapled to nuns. Yeah, it's Outlast alright. ._.

The Perks you can unlock and upgrade as you level up are great uses, and having a squad that can come in with different equipment can help you as you try and beat each game. There are unlockables you can use for your own little room to show off your own personal flair, but they're not really super satisfying to unlock. You can unlock some desk unique items for completing certain map challenges, but that's really about it when it comes to the cosmetics.

It's fun for a good while, but after you play through all the maps through all their difficulties so many times, you kinda lose interest as it gets a little easier to do every time. But I'd say the biggest letdown of this game is that there's far too little content to keep gauging my interest. It was fun, but in the end the $30 I spent on this game doesnt seem all that worth it when I only have 22 hours on this game.

I know we're only in 5 months on this game so far, but I feel like there 'should' be more, but there just isn't. And that's the biggest letdown of them all. I'd give it a thumbs up, but the above reasons are just why I can't. I'll come back to this game in a couple months to see if new content drops.

Outlast Trials is a fun stealth COOP game that will test your patience with the mission or it will test the patience with the knuckleheads you call friends. Each mission is in a distinct location with set objectives that will increase based on how many you have in your team. The first set of trials are not difficult and things get progressively easier as you level up on how you deal with threats and how you move about the map. There are quite a few types of roaming enemies and there are new threats based on the difficulty of the mission. There are various fun cosmetics you can unlock and to make your character look like a goofball as you run with your crew of clowns. The levels themselves look great and creepy as hell as each location will make you feel a bit uncomfortable as you play through the missions. So far I absolutely love this game and I have high hopes for it as the release more content. This game has loads of potential and I am hoping to see new types of enemies and new trials throughout the course of the game's life cycle.

The Outlast Trials" had the potential to be an innovative addition to the world of horror gaming, but it falls short in several key aspects, ultimately making it a lackluster experience. This essay will discuss the reasons why this game can be considered as "really bad," from its overreliance on shock value to its lack of content and disappointing AI.

First and foremost, the game's primary downfall is its blatant overuse of shock and gore. While horror games often aim to provoke fear and discomfort, "The Outlast Trials" seems to have confused genuine horror with gratuitous violence. The game frequently thrusts players into scenes of grotesque brutality, often veering into a realm of tastelessness. Shocking imagery and extreme violence are indeed essential elements of the horror genre, but "The Outlast Trials" takes it too far, sacrificing subtlety and storytelling for cheap thrills. The excessive violence, unappealing lechery, and over-the-top subject matter often leave players feeling desensitized rather than genuinely frightened. Instead of inducing genuine horror, the game often elicits eye-rolls and frustration.

Furthermore, the game's storytelling and narrative development are weak at best. It lacks a compelling and coherent storyline, opting for a shallow premise involving an evil corporation abducting individuals for "death games." The game's world-building is limited, and players must scavenge for tidbits of lore scattered throughout the levels, making it challenging to become emotionally invested in the game's world. The lack of a captivating narrative robs players of the opportunity to feel connected to the characters or immersed in the story, a critical aspect in the horror genre.

Another significant issue with "The Outlast Trials" is its underwhelming artificial intelligence (AI). The enemies, who should be the primary source of fear in a horror game, often come across as bumbling and unintelligent. They frequently get stuck or lose sight of the player when they should not, diminishing the sense of peril. This lack of intelligent AI results in an annoying rather than a genuinely terrifying gameplay experience. In a horror game, the enemies should be relentless, unpredictable, and smart, keeping players on edge throughout. Unfortunately, the AI's shortcomings rob players of the suspense and tension that is crucial to a horror game's success.

Moreover, the game's overall lack of content is a major drawback. With only three levels and a few variations, players can exhaust the available content in just a few hours. The limited variety of environments and scenarios contributes to a repetitive gameplay experience, making it challenging to maintain player interest over time. Additionally, two of the levels share a significant amount of content, making them feel less distinct and reducing the sense of novelty that each level should bring.

In conclusion, "The Outlast Trials" is a game that falls short of its potential as a horror gaming experience. Its excessive focus on shock value, lack of a compelling narrative, subpar AI, and limited content all contribute to an overall disappointing and underwhelming gaming experience. While the game's future updates may address some of these issues, it currently fails to deliver the gripping and immersive horror experience that gamers deserve.

Listen i love outlast. I have loved these games since i played the first one many many years ago. In fact the firs one if my favorite game of all time. So with that being said, I was VERY excited for this game. And then the game play teaser came out. I saw how you were able to 'defend' yourself against enemy's. I thought it wouldn't effect anything until i played the actual game. Playing both outlast 1 and 2 for years on the various difficulties, knowing where each jump scare is, knowing every shortcut, cut-seen, all words of dialogue, and just knowing every things there is to know about these games. I always thought these games were above all other horror/survivor games for many reasons. To list a few, the environments of the first two games were incredible, the soundtrack, the characters, the documents, the level design, and many many more. But what I thought to be the most pivotal part of the outlast games, was that you couldn't fight back. 

A major part of why this game was so terrifying to people is if you encountered a threat, you had no other option but to run away and hope you can hide to escape. This game basically takes that and throws it out of the window. You don't have to be scared if you have a stun because you can run straight to the killer knowing you can delay a chase. You can't do that in the previous installments which is why i love it. You have to be smart around the AI because they can kill you very quickly if you don't know the layout, where you're supposed to go, or where to even hide. In this game it can feel like you can have no idea where to go but you can have a 2 stuns that can help you search the map without a threat. Having to run away and not be able to fight back against something that is doing everything it can to kill you and all you have is you're ability to think on your feet. I love red barrels and I appreciate all the time it took to make this game. And I can appreciate them trying to take a step in a new direction, but I just feel like they fell a little flat. Don't get me wrong it's still a good horror game, but not as much as it could've been if they just followed their own formula. This feels like the assassins creed odyssey of the outlast franchise. Its a good horror game, it just doesn't feel like an outlast game.

P.S. I hope they add a single player campaign that follows a story like the previous installments. They do an amazing job at world building and making a interesting story that keeps you engaged start to finish. I know this is still early access, and i'm not trying to trash the developers, nor tarnish the game itself. And yes, I still recommend that you play this. It's still a game that does what it intends to do, which is to scare you. 

This review is just of a comment from a life long fan of your games! Thank you for everything you do red barrels!
