"The Outlast Trials" is a game that truly exceeded my expectations. As a fan of the Outlast series, I was eagerly anticipating this installment, and I can confidently say that it delivers an exceptional horror experience. What sets this game apart is its innovative approach to cooperative game-play in a genre known for its solitary scares.
The first thing that struck me was the atmospheric and chilling setting. The Cold War era backdrop adds a unique and unsettling dimension to the game, making it stand out from other horror titles. The attention to detail in the environment, from the dimly lit underground facilities to the eerie Soviet-era architecture, is nothing short of remarkable. It immerses you in a world that feels both authentic and terrifying.
The game-play mechanics are spot on. Teaming up with friends or AI companions adds an exciting layer of strategy and tension to the game. Cooperation is key to survival, and the way the game forces you to rely on each other for safety and progression is both challenging and exhilarating. Whether it's finding the next piece of the puzzle, covering each other in heart-pounding chase sequences, or simply trying to survive, "The Outlast Trials" keeps you on the edge of your seat.
The horror elements are executed masterfully. The game's sound design is hauntingly effective, and the jump scares are placed with precision. It's not just about gore and shock; the psychological horror elements are equally gripping. The game messes with your mind and constantly keeps you guessing, creating an atmosphere of genuine dread.
Furthermore, the story is intriguing and unfolds in a way that keeps you invested in the game world. The mysteries surrounding the experiments and the characters are compelling, and you'll find yourself eager to uncover the truth as you progress through the game.
In terms of graphics and optimization, "The Outlast Trials" runs smoothly on a variety of hardware configurations, and the visuals are top-notch. The character animations, lighting effects, and overall graphical fidelity contribute to the game's immersion.
In conclusion, "The Outlast Trials" is a remarkable addition to the horror genre. It successfully blends the trademark Outlast scares with innovative co-op game-play, resulting in an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a fan of the series or a newcomer to the franchise, this game is a must-play. Brace yourself for a heart-pounding adventure filled with dread, suspense, and unforgettable moments. Get ready to team up and survive together in the twisted world of "The Outlast Trials."

[strike]
I'm going to be 100% honest. I love this game, but it has serious flaws that just makes the experience so mute compared to Outlast 1 & 2.
First, the singleplayer. I've played this game exclusively solo and I can without a doubt say that the AI has regressed since Outlast 1 and even Outlast 2. Either half the time you're waiting for an enemy to leave or they just camp the objective and you have to play cat and mouse with them so they move away for long enough you can get something done.

The first exam is hard, and a good challenge for singleplayer, but the second main exams are bullsh*t beyond comprehension. I really gave the final exams a try but they are next to impossible to complete solo. All main enemies in the area will camp the objective and if you're going for a higher than D rank (which is most likely what you're getting) you're f*cked because you can't distract them because if you do it goes on your testing report and you get penalized. 

Now, I've TRIED to hide, even in the best circumstances it's about a 50/50 if I get found or not. Even if I haven't made any noise, and the noise stinger hasn't played, I will get found.

Now the things that really bug me. The dudes that hide in the closets and barrels. Most of the time you can't even see the visual cue they're there because either you're passing by or just looking for something else. They make no noise if you're running by and it because super tedious and annoying to deal with them where I just leave the trial and quit the game.

I understand Red Barrels went for something different with how the FPS camera is set up but it doesn't feel good at all. It feels like you're loosely in the shoes of whoever you're playing as and sometimes it's hard to read where you REALLY are (ex: sliding over a box to get away from someone) I could not tell you how many countless times I've thought I was completely out of the way of something and really wasn't so I either got hit, or died.

Too long kinda read;
AI camps objectives, aimlessly wanders. Bullsh*t hidden enemies that jump out at you. Singleplayer is terrible.

I honestly WOULD like this game if these issues weren't so apparent. The regular trials are fine but the average andy isn't going to be able to complete an exam on their own even though the game is ADVERTISED as singleplayer or multiplayer. It needs a heavy singleplayer rework for the exams.
[/strike]

Oh, gather 'round, my gaming friends, and lend an ear to me,
I've got a tale of terror, in a coop game you must see.
It's called the Outlast Trials, a frightful multiplayer delight,
With four brave souls together, we'll be scared all through the night!

Now, don't you worry, it's all in good fun, but grab your pals so tight,
For in this spine-chilling thriller, you'll need all the help in sight.
Four players in cahoots, exploring horrors in the dark,
But trust me when I say, it's a rollercoaster, not a walk in the park!

The graphics are so eerie, with shadows in every nook,
And the jump scares are aplenty; you won't know where to look.
You'll scream, you'll shout, you'll laugh until you cry,
As you and your brave comrades attempt not to die!

With flashlights flickering, and monsters on the prowl,
You'll race against the terror, with a nervous, sweaty scowl.
But the best part of this game, and let me make it clear,
Is watching your buddies jump, and squeal in mortal fear!

So, if you're seeking thrills and chills, with friends who won't bail,
The Outlast Trials is your ticket to a multiplayer horror tale.
Gather 'round, my gaming crew, and prepare for spooky spills,
In this coop horror adventure, that'll give you Outlast thrills!

If you're an Outlast fan you'll probably have a better time. My problem is probably just not being good enough at the game, but I find myself becoming frustrated very frequently while playing. I've only played co-op, but with any more than 2 players, the game became significantly less enjoyable. 

Difficulty scales with number of players. 2 players was great. Any more and it seemed like there was no escape from enemies, and on the chance I did get away, another would spawn soon after through the sliding doors placed throughout the level. If I had to guess, the intention is to use Rigs while playing with that many people to offset the increased difficulty.

Skill issues aside, my only real gripe with the game's design is the fact that after completing a trial, players need to go back to the beginning of said trial to leave. While I understand it makes sense in the game world (being sent on a test and needing to come back to be graded), it is extremely annoying. At the very least, I would expect multiple ways to return to the shuttle, yet I found myself constantly running in circles because "there was this one closed door" recessed in the shadows that I couldn't have noticed because my batteries ran out in the middle of my 9th chase.

Honestly there isn't much more I could ask from this game, it checks a lot of boxes for a fun horror co-op experience. Only a couple of things I hope will be added by full release or sooner. As someone who enjoys achievements because it gives me another reason to keep playing the game, I hope they will add achievements. One complaint I do have, I feel like the sneaking around could be fixed a bit more. A few times I would get spotted through walls or I'd get spotted when I'm not even exposed. I play a lot of stealth games and I love them, but it can get frustrating when you get punished over nothing because sneaking around is a lil buggy. One last thing, it would be super cool if there was a mechanic in the game where you can kill the smaller/basic enemies by sneaking up on them with a brick or bottle, also if you were to hit them enough times with throwables. Because a lot of times the basic enemies can just feel like a chore and less fun when there's so many and it would feel satisfying to fight back in some way. I think a way to balance that kind of killing mechanic though so is not to break the scary aspect and the pacing, maybe every time you kill a smaller enemy your sanity will start to decay with each kill and other enemies would get more aggressive. Especially the big bad of every map. I just think it would add more to the dynamic of the game if there was a way you can eliminate the small guys but at a risk. Other than that though. Outlast Trials: A Uniquely Cooperative Horror Experience

The Outlast Trials is a unique cooperative horror game set in the Cold War era. Players take on the role of test subjects in a mysterious government facility, where they are forced to participate in sadistic experiments. The game is currently in early access, but it already offers a compelling and terrifying experience.

One of the things that makes Outlast Trials so unique is its focus on cooperative gameplay. Players can work together to solve puzzles, complete objectives, and escape from danger. However, the game also introduces some interesting mechanics that can sow discord among teammates, such as doppelgangers that can attack players if they're not careful.

The Outlast Trials is also incredibly atmospheric. The game's environments are dark, claustrophobic, and filled with disturbing imagery. The sound design is also excellent, creating a truly tense and immersive experience.

Of course, no horror game would be complete without its fair share of scares. Outlast Trials delivers on this front, with a variety of jump scares and disturbing sequences that will keep players on the edge of their seats.

Overall, The Outlast Trials is a promising early access game that offers a unique and terrifying cooperative horror experience. Fans of the Outlast series will definitely want to check it out.

Here are some of the things I liked most about the game:

Unique cooperative gameplay: Working together with teammates to survive the horrors of the game is a lot of fun, but the doppelganger mechanic adds a nice layer of tension and distrust.
Atmospheric environments: The game's environments are dark, claustrophobic, and filled with disturbing imagery, creating a truly immersive experience.
Effective scares: Outlast Trials delivers a variety of jump scares and disturbing sequences that will keep players on the edge of their seats.

Though the game would have done better if it released finished with more content, it still delivers with its chilling scares, interesting maps, and its anxiously tense gameplay. If you're a fan of cooperative horror games, then I highly recommend checking out The Outlast Trials

The Outlast Trials" is a formidable addition to the Outlast franchise and a gripping survival experience in the world of video game horror. This game throws you into the midst of a malevolent experiment from the Cold War era, putting your survival skills to the test in an innovative way.

Pros:

Intense Horror Atmosphere: The game keeps you constantly on edge, making you feel like anything could happen at any moment. The sound and visual design contribute remarkably to this terrifying atmosphere.

Well-Designed Gameplay Mechanics: The Outlast Trials brings some interesting innovations in terms of gameplay mechanics. The ability to cooperate with other players to survive adds a new dynamic and raises the question of who can be trusted in such a situation.

Intriguing Story: The game features an intriguing story that reveals more about the Outlast universe, providing answers to questions fans have had for a long time.

Cons:

Some Bugs and Technical Issues: I experienced a few minor bugs that, while not significantly affecting the gameplay, could be improved through future updates.

Co-op Learning Curve: The game requires good coordination between cooperating players. Initially, this aspect might seem challenging for some players.

Overall, "The Outlast Trials" is a captivating horror experience worth exploring. Fans of the Outlast series will find many familiar elements and a story that ingeniously ties into previous events. Despite a few minor technical issues, the game offers a truly unique cooperative horror experience on the market.

This is definitely a title that horror genre enthusiasts and Outlast franchise fans shouldn't miss. Together with friends or other players online, get ready to step into a terrifying experiment and uncover the horrifying secrets of "The Outlast Trials." Enjoy the well-orchestrated fear and the grim atmosphere of this captivating game!

Honestly, Outlast Trials is outdoing most of the bigger games released in its time. Compared to other AAA games, outlast has little to no bugs, a solid gameplay loop, fits to its themes, has perfect/fitting voice acting, and delivers on a solid horror and co-op experience. It's even got lovely little details in the lobby, the minigames, the upgrades are built into the facility instead of just being a menu, and the story is fitting.

It's about time the co-op horror genre had a good entry.

All the elements and details play together well, the mechanics work to provide a solid experience, and the fact that foes can take you down in more ways than just one is a plus.

The only flaw is that it doesn't have enough trials, and that's a good flaw in this regards. It means that the trials/content/missions that are available are good, and have me thirsting for more.

The Outlast Trials did not get old for me quickly.
It took about 60 hours of playitme before I had to even take a break from the game. Once you max out a skill, the scares & excitement start to wear off a bit. 
Never really got tired of the trials themselves, the circus one is easily the worst (Especially the mannuequin children one where you have to backtrack from end to beginning) as sometimes games can just go on & on & on. 
Other than that, their variables + random generation are plentiful & you'll rarely ever notice a pattern repeat. Definitely the most impressive random generation I've seen in a game like this.
Something that would extend this games life cycle greatly would be an Asymmetrical game mode, except focus less on it being a sweat fest like DBD & more of just a new avenue to scare & excite players.
Customisation is brilliant & the biggest most common prize you receive for completing trials, its in abundance here. 
What kept me playing Outlast Trials is it's not very sweaty player base, 98% of players treat it as a horror game, which is what separates it from other games in it's genre.
Players have a pretty perfect level of fight back, I wish there would be an option to completely reset knowledge on your weapons with an encouraging cosmetic. 
The aesthetic of the game is one of the most impressive, immersive environments I've seen in recent gaming, the level of detail is staggering & everything works towards making the world scarier. You won't find a cosmetic with a monkey costume here. Everything fits the universe Red Barrels have built.

The Redbarrels team once again delivers with this third entry in the Outlast series. I was skeptical when I first heard this was a multiplayer game, but it seems to hit the balance perfectly between gameplay and atmosphere. The maps are so detailed and brimming with personality, as are the enemy characters and tone the game gives out. This is also the most diverse set of items/mechanics we've seen from the Outlast series yet. The addition of AMPS, modifiers, throwables, and a sanity system all make the game much more complex compared to the first two games. I would say the only downside (and I'm reaching) is the lack of intractability enemies have with the player outside of just attacking. To make the game work with multiple people most instances of story-based interactions with the player or situation-changing events are gone.

[h1] Deserves Game of The Year [/h1]

This game is a rollercoaster of fear, survival, and psychological torment, and I must say, it's one of the most engaging horror games I've ever played.

From the moment I stepped into the dark and foreboding world of The Outlast Trials, I knew I was in for something special. The game plunges you into the midst of the Cold War era, where you're trapped in a disturbing experiment orchestrated by a malevolent organization. The atmosphere is thick with tension, and every corner of the eerie facility feels like it's hiding secrets and horrors just waiting to be uncovered.

The Outlast Trials is a masterpiece of horror gaming. It's a game that gets under your skin and refuses to let go, thanks to its engaging gameplay, well-balanced difficulty, and expertly crafted atmosphere. My heart raced, my palms sweated, and my mind was thoroughly twisted by this psychological nightmare, and I loved every minute of it. Thank you, Red Barrel, for once again proving why you are the masters of horror.

The sound design and visuals are nothing short of exceptional. The hauntingly realistic audio cues had me jumping at every distant creak and whisper. The visuals are nightmarishly beautiful, with grimy, and especially dimly lit environments that draw you deeper into the madness. The character designs are grotesque and unforgettable, and they will haunt my nightmares for weeks to come.

What truly sets this game apart is its accessibility. The Outlast Trials manages to strike a balance that caters to all ranges of players. The difficulty settings are thoughtfully designed, allowing newcomers to the horror genre to enjoy the story without feeling overwhelmed, while veteran horror enthusiasts can crank up the challenge for a truly heart-pounding experience. It's a rare feat in the world of horror games, and Red Barrel deserves praise for it.

If you're a fan of horror games, "The Outlast Trials" is a must-play. Just be prepared to lose sleep and question your sanity in the process.

Thank you again Red Barrels for giving this gift to us to enjoy, and I hope to see more outstanding development from this wonderful team.

Fried rice recipe (serves 5 ppl)

Ingredients:

- 5 c day old white rice
- 1/4 c oyster sauce
- 1/4 c soy sauce
- 2 tsp MSG
- 2 chicken breasts 
- 1-2 c cremeni mushrooms 
- 1c frozen veggies (corn, carrot, peas)
- 5 garlic cloves (sliced or minced)
- garlic salt
- 1/2 onion (sliced)
- 1 bell pepper (juliened) (optional)
- 2 green onion/scallions (sliced) (optional)

Instructions:

1) in a large bowl, separate your day old rice by crushing chunks of rice using your hands. Rinse your hand in cold water to prevent rice from sticking to your hand

2) add oil (about 3-5 tbsp) to a large pan or wok and wait till it's hot (medium high heat)

3) slice or chop your mushrooms into your desired sizes

4) cut your chicken breast into bite sizes pieces. Add salt to taste and let it dry brine

5) add your mushrooms and sauté until tender. Add a few pinches of fresh ground black pepper and garlic salt during the process.

6) once your mushrooms are done, set aside and remove any excess liquid in your pan and change your oil if necessary

7) add your chicken and cook until crisp or tender (up to you). Add salt and pepper to taste

8) set chicken aside and sautee your onions and garlic. If you decide to add bell peppers, sauté them with the garlic and onions

9) once the garlic and onions (and bell peppers) are tender, add your rice and mushrooms and mix

10) mix your oyster and soy sauce. 

11) add your sauce into rice and mix

12) add your msg and mix. Add garlic salt and fresh ground pepper to taste.

13) add your frozen veggies, mix then cover your rice with a lid and let steam (5-8 minutes)

14) serve with scallions (optional) and enjoy

(Adding freshly scrambled eggs is also a good idea but is optional)
A good game
Great with friends

This game genuinely surprised me. I love horror games, but was unsure how this multiplayer style of game would be. And it can be tense, even with three friends. Probably one of the best co-op horror game experiences I have had. 

My only gripe would be lack of content. It's fun to replay levels to try beating your score, but eventually those get played out. Especially once you master a certain level. There are 9 levels in total in the base game across three locations. And there are additional "levels" that act as more difficult versions of previous levels. But the difficulty spikes also cause you to try different strategies, so it does feel like a new experience on higher difficulties. But again, the low amount of content can indeed be a bummer because the game is so fun.

But everything else about the game is fantastic. Highly recommended if you have friends to play with.

Been looking for a game like this for a looong time. There are few horror games that pull off progression and above all replayability. Can probably count them with one hand. Some have gone too far from horror, so maybe even less. As it stands, this is an absolute banger of a game.

That being said, my only concern for the future of Outlast Trials is it being always online. Its an Early Access, but its such a solid experience, both solo and coop. It may seem like such a small thing to worry about now, but as much as I hope for a bright future ahead of it, there's a chance something might go wrong, and this gem goes offline forever.

Just to end it as a little letter to any dev that might stumble upon this review, thank you. There's so much love and effort put into this game, and it shows. I could nerd out on everything I love about it, but it all sums up to this, the care a small dedicated team, willing to go through their own trials to bring out such a solid game. No editions, no microtransactions, no passes, an actual game.

Once again Red Barrels has delivered; giving us horror fans a game we can be not only be terrified by but a game that has us wanting more. The first in the series to be fully multiplayer Outlast Trials allows you team up with your friends to solve puzzles and stealth your way to escape across numerous maps and missions in the hopes of earning your way out of the system and to freedom. Choices must be made as you decide whether or not to help your fellow "inmates" as you fight for top grades which not only give you revenue, but unlock harder missions in order for you to earn the chance to escape the experiment you are stuck in. Support for this game has been amazing, as the devs listen to every complaint and concern, making changes to better the game for all players as well as presenting us with new updates constantly with much more planned down the road.

In terms of Gameplay, I know it's not for everyone. This is fine. But for those looking for a thrilling horror game to play with friends, this is that game. I'm not even joking. I always wanted a co-op horror game that didn't feel so gimmicky/competitive since every multiplayer game is competitive nowadays. I understand that this game is early access, but for what it has for now, it's wonderfully rewarding. I feel incentivised to run through each trial and aim for a higher score, meeting people who have a similar mindset, and reading over the hidden files that game has scattered across the maps. It's even crazier that this game's co-op experiences is treated as such. You can't do everything alone without going through great difficulty. You also have different roles that people can play to make running through trials a lot easier. Strategy, of running through, horrors of the location and the killers' themes. The puzzles that are fair but very slow burning(for the first time around).  And as a bonus, this game is coming to console!
One thing I worry about is the microtransations and the longevity of the games life. It's a great game that I can play for hours on end, but this game is simply not for everyone. So I pitched(as well as many others) that their should be a way to create your own trails/ experiences since I can see how big this game can get. For those who are on the edge wondering whether or not they should get this game, do it! For those who are a bit more apprehensive, try to get it with a friend so you guys can suffer together! Red Barrels, keep up the great work!

[h1]A Dream of Strange Cities[/h1]

[i]There sat down, once, a thing on Henry's heart
só heavy, if he had a hundred years
& more, & weeping, sleepless, in all them time
Henry could not make good.
Starts again always in Henry's ears
the little cough somewhere, an odour, a chime.

And there is another thing he has in mind
like a grave Sienese face a thousand years
would fail to blur the still profiled reproach of.  Ghastly,
with open eyes, he attends, blind.
All the bells say: too late. This is not for tears;
thinking.

But never did Henry, as he thought he did,
end anyone and hacks her body up
and hide the pieces, where they may be found.
He knows: he went over everyone, & nobody's missing.
Often he reckons, in the dawn, them up.
Nobody is ever missing.[/i]

John Berryman, [i]Dream Song 29[/i]

- Look for rectangular blue buttons stamped with the Murkoff logo, then use your middle mouse key or voice chat to call a friend over to press the second one simultaneously. You'll unlock a room filled with goodies. The buttons and the room are always very close to each other.

- Blue document folders are like crack for you. Grab them, always.

- Never play solo. You can adjust your matchmaking settings to only join groups of 4, which is ideal.

- On harder Trial difficulties bottles and bricks to the head don't seem to do much to enemies. You need to use the explosive Rig or avoid them completely. Enemies will also be more likely to check hiding spots and pull you out.

- A special sound effect will always play when an enemy spots or hears you. You have a few seconds to leave or hide when this happens. Being detected by enemies never reduces your score, but being hit and stepping on noisemakers does even if you have the Slippers equipped.

- Your middle mouse button can't mark the Pouncers in hiding spots even if you're pointing right at them. You'll have to use voice chat to warn people.

- The Giant's axe is a one-hit KO and his reach is always longer than you think.

- In Trials, the people standing or sitting alone will hit you if you go near them.

- In the carnival you're meant to grab hearts from the steel bin in the diner to get tickets. I mention this because me and everyone I played with had no idea you could interact with what we thought was just a gory detail - we spent like 20 minutes hunting for bricks and bottles to hit the targets.

- You can't time the flame jets in the river of blood to get past them. Don't even try.

- When a Prime Asset is holding someone else you have a few seconds to run over and boot them loose. The same goes for downed players being executed, but you'll have to run in a circle so you can lose the enemy, then double back and revive him.

- You're going to lose a few Trials because you got stuck with a stupid team that doesn't cooperate.

Finally, a new outlast game. And even better, it's MULTIPLAYER! Groundbreaking.
Imagine this, the traditional outlast formula, with all the hiding, running and pissing yourself, but you can now slightly slow down the enemy. Gamechanging.
I will say this, if you don't have friends, get some and buy this game. It's worth it. But really, from my experience, it's really damn difficult if on the highest level. Shit, it's difficult on almost all levels, especially alone. In my quest to get every level to an A+, I had to turn everything to a science, memorize how the lunatics move, what they do, how close I can get without getting my ass beat. Really damn difficult, but a great time. Sometimes if you get caught by what my friends and I call "tweakers", that is, the men that stand in place and scream, immobilizing you for an excessive amount of time, which allows the man who is now inside my asshole to royally ruin my entire year, making me have to reset the level. Also, there have been a few times where I have been insta killed, like being immobilized on an electric trap because I was running from a man, but was stunned by a tweaker directly on top of the trap, and it activated, bringing my health low enough to be oneshotted by the man who is now balls deep in my colon.
9/10 Buy this game

Ps. Men chase you with their dicks out all the time, I would 100% recommend this.

The Outlast Trials is shaping up to be a fantastic co-op horror experience, albeit one that isn’t overly scary. An intriguing setup, well-crafted loadout systems and an emphasis on cooperation make it a grotesquely violent and appealing game, even in this early stage. The solo experience is however, as miserly as the inhabitants of this disturbed asylum, so plot your escape with others, or suffer the consequences.

But Overall a fun "Party game" if a bit ultra Violent

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my daughter, who is 14 now. My daughter got this game last Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and she started playing. By the end of the week she had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my daughter, as she is always out with her friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside her. I loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my daughter for help and she invited me to a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my daughter since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my daughter closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my daughter many happy memories.

Thank you Outlast Trial

polished, enjoyable with a crew of people that don't get enraged and can speak english (dont try the lfg on the discord), looks good, had an absolute blast when it came to early access and it was the first time since probably 2011 where everyone actually talked and joked around and made friends instead of 90% of online games now where everyone is a frail nerd terrified of speaking cause the vibrations might shatter their bones, surprisingly there wasnt that many weak twitch streamer types because initially they were filtered by nudity and gore, so you didn't have numales crying about what some random chinese guy screamed into his mic or have some fake youtuber personality guy talking constantly and not helping, it was actually cool to see people relaxed, careless, joking around and having fun instead of endlessly seething. got bored of the same 3 levels and 2 killers on repeat so i stopped playing since it came to early access, there has been nothing new since the project omega update which didnt even add any new things. no communication from the devs, no news posts or anything, avg players went from 19k to 1500 now. its probably dead now?
